Construction Report and Accounts
for Irrigation Pumping Plant
and Distribution System for the
Kamloops Industrial School.

Sir:-

you from the Indian Department on April 13th., last, we
proceeded with the construction of the irrigation pumping
plant for the Kamloops Industrial School. We have superintended

and ditches necessary to get the water on the land. The whole
system is now completed and has been in successful operation
for several days.

I am enclosing herewith the following accounts which

The original estimate for the pumping plant and transmission line as given in my preliminary report, dated March 30th., 1918, was for $2800.00. In my letter of April 26th., 1918, I explained the necessity for making a change in the plans for the transmission line in order to avoid an excessive annual rental charge, and estimated the extra cost at $300.00. This brought the total estimate up to $3100.00.

The actual cost of the pumping plant, including the pipe line and transmission line, was $3336.58, so that we exceeded the estimates on the plant by $236.58, which is less than 8% of the estimated cost.

In addition to the pumping plant, with its transmission line and pipe line, we superintended the construction of the main distribution ditches. In the original report, there was no estimate included for this work, since the general opinion of everyone concerned seemed to be that earth ditches would be all that would be necessary, and that the pupils at the Industrial
School would be able to dig them without much expense to the Department. Under the circumstances, and on account of the short length of time at our disposal, we did not make definite surveys for the distribution system, nor did we included an estimate of its cost in the preliminary report.

The small amount of the actual cash expenditure for the construction of the earth ditches is shown by the fact that only some $50.00 was spent on the 2 miles dug, since nearly all the work was done by the pupils of the Industrial School. If we had been able to use earth ditches entirely, as was originally supposed the cost of the distribution system would have been comparatively small.

When we came to examine carefully the actual conditions, after work was started on the construction of the pumping plant, we found that a considerable length of flumes would be necessary, and that the expense for the distributing system would be quite a considerable item. However, the pumping plant would be useless without the distribution system, and there was no time to spare if the necessary work was to be done before the river rose, and if the water was to be ready in time to save this season's crop. Under these circumstances, we decided to proceed with the extra work and carry it out as speedily and economically as possible, consistent with good workmanship.

The accompanying plan shows the extent of the distribution system as actually built. There are 2 miles of earth ditches and 2260 feet of substantial lumber flumes supported on trestles from 1 to 5 feet high. The whole system is proportioned according to the amount of land to be served and the water to be carried. The actual cash outlay on the ditches, as already mentioned, was only about $50.00. The flumes, on the other hand, cost $470.00 for lumber and material and $440.00 for labor, making a total of $910.00, which was 40¢ per lineal foot.

Some outlying parts of the ditch system have not been finished yet, but the land they are to serve will not be irrigated this year.
Nearly all the surveys have been made, and with the exception of 2 road crossings the work will be all earth ditches which can be dug by the pupils at the Industrial School at little extra expense. The Provincial Public Works engineer is talking of moving the road, and if this is done before the ditches are needed, the road crossings will not be required.

In spite of our hurry, the river rose before the well could be dug as deep as our plans called for. This will prevent the use of the pumping plant when the river is very low. There will not likely be any trouble in the fall, but there might be in the early spring. During the low water period this fall or next spring, the well should be deepened 2 feet and the connecting box uncovered and lowered the same amount. This will probably cost less than $100.00.

In previous years, some 10 or 12 acres of the most favorably located land has been irrigated by the use of the following machinery, which will not be needed any more in its present location:

- 1 - 4" x 6" Gasoline engine belt-connected to 3" centrifugal pump.
- 1 - 4" x 6" Gasoline engine belt-connected to 2" centrifugal pump.
- 2 - windmills and well pumps. One windmill wheel broken.

On June 14th., we made a test of the new pumping plant to determine its general capacity and efficiency. The plant was supposed to deliver 1000 gallons (U.S.) per minute or 2.2 cubic feet per second, at a static head of 50 feet. When the test was made the river was high and the head was only 41 feet. This decrease would be expected to cause an increase in the capacity and probably a decrease in the efficiency.

The actual test gave a discharge of 2.7 cubic feet per second or 1200 gallons per minute, which shows that the plant has the required capacity. The efficiency of the machinery, making an allowance of 16 feet for friction loss in the pipes and elbows,
was 59%, which is considered quite satisfactory for this type of pump, especially when operating under a varying head.

The actual ratio of the useful work done in lifting the water to the amount of power through the meter, which gives the over-all efficiency of the plant, was 42%. When the river is lower, there will be a smaller discharge and the friction loss will be less, so that the over-all efficiency will generally be somewhat higher.

In designing the plant, a higher efficiency could have been obtained by using larger pipe and more expensive machinery, but the extra expenditure could not be justified for a plant like this, where the annual power charges will probably not greatly exceed 10% on the first cost of the plant.

The amount of current consumed in delivering the 1200 gallons per minute, was 22 kilowatts per hour, so that at $1.37 per kilowatt-hour, the cost of operating the pump was 33 cents per hour. This season, with some 45 acres of land under cultivation, it should not be necessary to run the pump for more than 4 or 5 hours a day.

In contrasting the cost of supplying irrigation water by pumping with the cost by a gravity system, it should be remembered that the cost of the distribution system is the same in both cases and depends entirely on the general configuration of the land to be irrigated. In this case, however, it is unfortunate that no estimate was made of the cost of the distribution system, since it was a necessary part of the whole irrigation scheme. The omission only affected the preliminary report, and did not increase the actual cost of the work in any way.

The cost of the pumping plant itself, including the pipe line and transmission line, exceeded the estimates by less than 8%; the work on the flumes and ditches was done as economically
as possible; and the whole plant and distribution system has been successfully completed in time to irrigate this season's crop.

The original estimate for the pumping plant and transmission line as given in my preliminary report, dated March 30th., 1916, was for $2600.00. In my letter of April 26th., 1916, I explained the necessity for making a change in the plans for the transmission line in order to avoid an excessive annual rental charge, and estimated the extra cost at $300.00. This brought the total estimate up to $3100.00.

The actual cost of the pumping plant, including the pipe line and transmission line, was $3336.58, so that we exceeded the estimates on the plant by $236.58, which is less than 8% of the estimated cost.

In addition to the pumping plant, with its transmission line and pipe line, we superintended the construction of the main distribution ditches. In the original report, there was no estimate included for this work, since the general opinion of everyone concerned seemed to be that earth ditches would be all that would be necessary, and that the pupils at the Industrial School would be able to dig them without much expense to the Department. Under the circumstances, and on account of the short length of time at our disposal, we did not make definite surveys for the distribution system, nor did we included an
estimate of its cost in the preliminary report.

The small amount of the actual cash expenditure for the construction of the earth ditches is shown by the fact that only some $50.00 was spent on the 2 miles dug, since nearly all the work was done by the pupils of the Industrial School. If we had been able to use earth ditches entirely, as was originally supposed the cost of the distribution system would have been comparatively small.

When we came to examine carefully the actual conditions, after work was started on the construction of the pumping plant, we found that a considerable length of flumes would be necessary, and that the expense for the distributing system would be quite a considerable item. New Irrigation Scheme Inaugurated 31st May.

Thanks to Mr. Duncan C. Scott, Deputy Superintendent General of Indian affairs, a new irrigation plant has just been installed at the Indian Industrial School, Kamloops. This work has been successfully carried through by Johnson & Co., Kamloops, with Mr. C. D. Cline, Division Engineer, and Mr. A. M. Phillips as surveyor. The ditches were dug by the boys of the school, the total cost to the Government will be in the neighborhood of $3,500. It is estimated that the plant, which is run by a 25-h.p. A. C. motor, is capable of supplying 1,000 gallons per minute sufficient to irrigate 100 acres. The electricity is supplied by the City at the rate of 1½ cents per kilowatt hour. Up to the present the school officials, through lack of water, have not been able to cultivate more than four or five acres. But this year they are putting under cultivation 45 acres, and it is devoutly hoped that this area will be further increased next year. The soil around the school is excellent, so that the new plant will be of great benefit to the Institution.

Father Welch, O.M.I., who happened to be on a visit to the school, came forward by the Engineer to push back the electric switch and set the machinery in motion. A few seconds later a stream of water was seen gushing from the six-inch pipe into the flume and ditch, and thence through a hundred little channels over the thirsty land. A ringing cheer from Mr. Calderwood’s pupils announced the happy completion of an important and much appreciated undertaking.

Father Desmarais, O.M.I., was absent at the time on business in Vancouver. We congratulate him on having acquired this splendid water system for his school farm. It will assuredly enable the children and staff of this well-conducted establishment to live in the years to come at least in frugal comfort.

Sir:

It has been reported to me from Kamloops that the Indian Agent was getting the Indians to agitate for a pumping system on the Reserve to irrigate their lands, which are at present very much in need of more water, if cultivation of their land is to be prosecuted by them successfully.

It may be possible, however, that the Indians may have thought of it themselves as the result of what they have seen accomplished at the Industrial School, and the Agent may be in no way to blame for the question coming up at this time. I notice the Agent makes reference to the movement in his monthly report for February, but gives no hint of the origin.

In view of the possibility of the Department entertaining the proposition for taking over the Harper Ranch for the Indians of Kamloops band, who would be asked to give up their present holding on the flat, it would seem to be an unwise course, at the present time, to introduce an agitation for the expenditure of Indian funds for
a pumping plant, as it would tend to prejudice them against the course which would tend to their greater advancement, both morally and materially, and would solve their irrigation difficulties in quite another and more effective way.

I shall endeavor, in the meanwhile, to ascertain from Mr. Smith the origin of the movement for pumping plant to which he makes reference in his report, and if the scheme was suggested to them by him, I think he should be given to understand that the proper course, under the circumstances, would have been to ascertain first the Department's wishes and intentions, before projecting any other course that would tend to forestall or embarrass. He has always opposed the policy of having the Indians give up their dwellings in the village and move on to their land and the pumping scheme takes on the appearance of an insidious move to give further effect to that opposition.

REPORT

Re- Installation of Domestic Water Supply System
Kamloops Industrial School

Sir:

At the request of Father McQuire, Principal of the Kamloops Industrial School, and after a thorough examination of existing conditions, this office prepared and submitted to the Indian Department, a report covering two alternative schemes, to provide the Industrial School with an adequate supply of water for domestic purposes.

On November 1st the Indian Department notified this office that they had selected one of the proposals, and requested us to proceed with the installation of the plant as soon as possible.

Acting upon this request tenders were called for as follows:
1) The supply of the machinery
2) The building of a pump house and the installation of the machinery
3) The construction of 350 feet of 220-volt pole line and the supply of 2-7 kwh transformers.

The installation of this water supply system was duly completed and the plant placed in operation on January 7th 1921.

Old Water Supply System

Previous to the installation of the new plant, the water supply for the Industrial School was obtained by means of a 5 H P gasoline engine, belt connected to a 6" x 6" reciprocating pump which supplied about 40 U.S. gallons per minute through a 2" pipe line, 400 ft length delivering water into two wooden storage tanks located in the school building, and having a combined capacity of 4000 U.S. gallons.

(a) The use of these tanks at such a low elevation was objectionable, as they supplied water at too low a pressure for satisfactory service, and were practically useless in case of fire; while in cold weather it was necessary to supply extra heating arrangements to prevent them from freezing.

(b) The cost of operating this system with gasoline was expensive, and considerable trouble was experienced in keeping the pump operating successfully on account of the high suction lift.

(c) The foundations of the tanks and machinery were found to be in a bad state of repair, and it was considered inadvisable to attempt any reconstruction of the existing system.
Present Water Supply System

(Electric Hydro-pneumatic pumping plant)

The present water supply is obtained by means of a 4" x 6" reciprocating double acting pump, belted to a 2 H. P. A.C. 3 phase, 60 cycle, 220-volt induction motor, having a capacity of 1200 U.S. gallons per hour; and delivering water against a maximum pressure of 50 lbs per sq. in., to a steel pressure tank of 1200 U.S. gallons capacity, situated 400 feet from the main building of the Kamloops Industrial School.

The pump is automatically controlled by an air pressure pilot diaphragm switch operating an electric control switch, so regulated that the pump will commence to operate when the pressure in the tank falls below 22 lbs per sq. in., and pump water until the pressure in the tank reaches 50 lbs per sq. in.

The water from the pressure tank is delivered to the Industrial School service pipes, direct, by means of a 8" supply pipe 400' in length, and without the use of any further storage tanks.

The pressure tank and pump are installed in a concrete and wood pump house near the South Thompson River and extra precautions have been taken to guard against freezing during cold weather by making all the walls of double thickness, the space between them being filled with sawdust.

A shifting valve situated on the outside of the pump casing provides the correct amount of air necessary in the pressure tank and a safety relief valve has been installed in the line between the pressure tank and the supply pump.

The whole system which requires very little attention to keep it operating satisfactorily is compact and positive in action, and will deliver 20 U.S. gals per minute continuously.

Cost of Installation and Cost of Operation

The total cost of construction of the above water supply system amounted to $912.60 and the cost of operation for the first four weeks after its installation amounted to $2.85 or an average operating cost of $27.00 per year.

Remarks

Upon its completion the above plant was handed over to Father Mcuire for the use of the Kamloops Industrial School, and I understand from him that it has to date given every satisfaction.

Up to the present no adequate provision has been made to guard against the possible outbreak of fire in the school premises and as the school itself and all the surrounding buildings are constructed entirely of wood I have attached to this report an appendix "A" dealing with this phase of the situation.

APPENDIX "A"

Memorandum re - Fire Protection

Kamloops Industrial School

The Kamloops Industrial School consists of several frame structures the largest of these being the two main school buildings of two stories each, occupied both night and day by some 40 or 50 pupils and members of the staff.

These buildings are situated 3 miles from the nearest fire engine station and depend at present for their fire protection on several small hand-operated chemical fire extinguishers located in various parts of the buildings. No hydrants of any kind have been installed for use in case of fire beyond the ordinary water taps in the wash basins and bathrooms.

Any outbreak of fire under existing conditions unless noticed immediately and controlled by one or more of the chemical fire extinguishers would in all probability result in the buildings being completely destroyed, with a possible loss of life among the pupils, for the following reasons:

The buildings are constructed entirely of wood which has thoroughly dried out from being in use for a long period and are situated in an exposed position subject to high winds at all seasons of the year. They contain narrow passages and steep stairways, and the pupils being situated at night time on the second floor, many of them would be forced to use these means of exit in case of an emergency.

The first few minutes after the discovery of a fire often decide whether the building can be saved or is to become a total loss and under the present system the only water that would be available in case of fire would have to be obtained in buckets from one or more of the standard 3/8" taps located in the wash basins and bathrooms.

The new water supply system can at very little extra expense be adapted for use in the event of fire, and the installation of 4 standard fire hydrants would more than double the present chances of successfully fighting any outbreak which may occur.

The capacity of the pump supplying water to the Industrial School is 20 U.S. gals. per min. on 2 - 3 inch nozzles so placed as to be available could deliver 80 U.S. gal. per min. from the storage tank, against a fire and maintain the flow for a period of 4 minutes; at the end of this time the pump would commence to operate and deliver a supply of 20 U.S. gals. per min. continuously.
With this system a total of 320 U.S. gals. would be available during the first 4 minutes and 20 U.S. gals. per min. thereafter.

In view of these facts I would recommend that 4 standard fire hoses equipped with 3" fire fighting nozzles be installed, two in each building and suitably connected to the present water system.

Dear Doctor:

Let me say in reference to your letter of Sep 2nd-34-1874 that we like your way of dealing. We always know what we are doing; if you can grant a request you say "yes," if you cannot grant it, you say just as emphatically "no." We find this a great advantage; we always know the basis of action. There are no rash steps. Whatever progress is made is solid.

Likewise we wish you to know our position and views. A pump thrown on the side of a river with an electric wire attached is not an irrigation system. The work of the engineers must be revised in view of local requirements and conditions, improved upon, solidified, turned into a permanent system. Who would do this for the Indian people? And who would pay for it?

2. But supposing the pump running: Who should say, "To-day we will start the pump running." Who will divide the water? And especially who will see that every man given water is there to do his irrigation?

3. And at the end of each month who pays for the electric current? Installation is one thing; cost of current is quite a different thing.

There are difficulties that arise the moment the current is turned on and they mean expense. They call for business abilities not possessed by Indians. These difficulties, however, may be met and
overcome by the Department. And if you were dealing with pupils from the school the first two difficulties would disappear.

But for us: In a system of that kind could we do much to aid or supervise? I do not think so. To aid we would need under us both the pump and the people. We would then be responsible for all three difficulties. However, this is not connected with the last paragraph; emphatically it is not a suggestion for the Department to confer the pump or its supervision upon us.

However, the land West of the school, as far as the main road running North, could be irrigated and supervised from the school, if school pupils were placed upon it. We would then have under us both the pumps and the people. This may look bad from the road, but business in business and facts—well I suppose they are the brute beasts of the intellectual domain;—we cannot control their looks.

But Kamloops Reserve is only one twelfth of the question. And on the other Reserves the difficulty is for the Indian Agent to secure for the pupil before he leaves school a well defined piece of land. We, then, as a rule can do the supervising. Is this always easy to secure? It is not. We know the difficulties with which you and the Agent have to contend. But as expressed in
a previous letter, any strength you can lend to the authority of the Indian Agent in this matter tends to the progress and betterment of our Indian people.

This letter goes by the hands of the Agent. Four big boys, and good ones, were discharged during the quarter without us being able to raise a hand to help them settle down on the land. We know the difficulties you and the Agent have; we are not complaining. We simply wish to make our position clear, so as to help you in any way we can to overcome these difficulties.

Yours very truly,

James McQuire O.M.I.

Sir:-

With reference to your request of December 8th, regarding the cost of enlarging the present irrigation pumping plant at the Kamloops Industrial School, I would state that in order to obtain sufficient water for irrigation purposes to supply the land you mention, it will be necessary to increase the capacity of the present pumping plant from 1,000 U.S. gallons per minute (which is its present capacity) to 3,000 U.S. gallons per minute, i.e. by supplying an additional 2,000 U.S. gallons per minute.

There are two ways by which this may be accomplished. It is possible to leave the present pumping plant as it stands and construct nearby at a cost of $4,200.00, which will bring the combined capacity of the two plants up to 3,000 U.S. gallons per minute; or it is possible to abolish the present pumping unit and remodel the existing pump house so that it will be large enough to house a new unit of 3,000 U.S. Gallons per minute capacity. This will entail a total expenditure of $4,800.00.

In either case the present well and intake pipe can be utilized, but new discharge pipe must be installed no matter which scheme is adopted. From an operating viewpoint the installation of one pump of 3,000 U.S. gallons per minute capacity will be more economical than the installation of a second pump to bring the capacity up to the required amount, as 75 H.P. will be required to operate a 3,000 gallon per minute pump, whereas the total H.P. required to operate two pumps (one 1,000 G.P.M. and one 2,000 G.P.M.) will amount to 85 H.P. From this it will be seen that if one unit is adopted a continuous saving of 10 H.P. in the operating costs can be effected over that of the double unit installation.

Moreover, there will be available for disposal by sale or use on some other location,

1 1,000 U.S. gallons per minute centrifugal pump;
1 25 H.P. 200 volt, 3 phase, 60 cycle, squirrel cage, induction motor, complete with starter switches, overload and low voltage release; and
1 set of 2200 volt--220 volt step-down transformers.

A very conservative estimate of the value of the above equipment which will be available for disposal would be $500.00, as no pumping unit of 1,000 gallons per minute capacity similar to the above can be obtained at the present time in this locality, even second hand, for less than this amount.

Father McGuire agrees to irrigate these two plots from his pump at the school for the time being, and put the boys under the instruction and supervision of Mr. Webb, who has been employed by the School as a Farming Instructor, pending the decision by the Department as to whether or no they are going to employ a man to instruct these ex-pupils set on these various lots.

Father, he will lend them the school team and implements to work their respective places, and also assist them in the building of their houses when such time arrives that the two boys get married and live on their places. Father in return for any work in which they might assist him.

It will therefore be seen, provided the Department approves of the suggestion to appropriate the 70 acres belonging to Chief Elie Larue as suggested above, that a sum, not exceeding $1000.00 be granted, to be divided as follows:- $700.00 to Chief Elie Larue and the 10 or 12 acres at present owned by Basil Francis but distant from the School, the remaining $300.00 to be utilized in the fencing of the 2-35 acre plots to be made out of the division of the said 70 acres, one for Basil Francis and one for Raymond Peter.

Dear Agent:

We need more land at the School. There are three ways of securing it, viz: 1. To buy a ranch; 2. To secure some Reserve land west of the School; or 3. To increase our present arable land by draining the lake on our land in front (South) of the School. Of the last proposition I wish to speak at present.

By putting in a dike on the South river bank and another West of the Lake, the lake itself could be drained. At least we think so, and it would be worth trying as it would add some twenty-five acres to our arable land. The cost would be trifling as we could do the work ourselves.

Both dikes would be on the Reserve. It would necessitate buying of four or five acres from them.

The water comes into the Lake from the South Thompson and from the West from the North Thompson flooding most of the Reserve land west of the school and enabling the Indians to cut from it a little wild hay. They fear if the break in the bank at the south were diked, sufficient water to flood their land would not come in from the west. To my mind the water is of the same level at both ends.

As we have high water here in May and June when the flooding occurs, kindly request the Department to have the Water Power Branch here make the observations necessary here next month. It would furnish definite information.

Yours very truly,

Sir:-

In reply to your letter above referred to I have the honour to submit herewith the plan forwarded, with the necessary information marked thereon as requested.

You will note that the three pieces of land in question referred to in Rev. Father's letter of May 11th, are outlined in red and marked 1, 2, and 3 respectively.

As suggested in the Rev. Father's letter, provided the Department can see its way clear, scheme No. 3, is more favoured than the other two, particularly No. 2, for the reasons stated in the Rev. Father's letter, as he does not wish to create any unpleasant feelings between the school and the Indians by taking land from Chief Elie Larue or anybody else.

In view of these circumstances, I most respectfully submit that the suggestions contained in my letter of May 26th be laid in abeyance until the Department has definitely decided which of the three plans it prefers to adopt.

You can readily see that as soon as the new school is completed, the land already allotted to the school will be insufficient for the upkeep of the full 250 pupils which it proposes to have in residence at the school, consequently more land must be obtained for the school sooner or later, and the best time to have this matter settled is before the actual time required, which I anticipate will not be more than twelve months hence.

If there is any further information required which I can give, I shall be only too pleased to do whatever I can to further the project either one way or the other.

Sir:

In accordance with instructions contained in your letter of January 26th., an investigation having reference to the amount of irrigable land which is available for farming purposes at the Kamloops Industrial School has been carried out by this office, and in this connection I would report to you as follows:

DESCRIPTION OF SCHOOL-

The Kamloops Industrial School, which is situated on the Kamloops Indian Reserve on the north bank of the South Thompson River at a distance of three miles from the City of Kamloops, is at the present time in the course of construction, and when completed will be of sufficient size to accommodate 150 persons.

This building, which
This building, which is being constructed in three portions, is at this date only two-thirds completed, i.e., the centre portion and the east wing have been built but there yet remains the west wing to be constructed.

The completed portions of the above building are in occupation at the present time by members of the staff and pupils, numbering in all a total of 140 persons.

DESCRIPTION OF SCHOOL LANDS-

The Kamloops Industrial School property, which is situated immediately surrounding the school buildings, comprises an area of approximately 263 acres. (See accompanying plan)

Of this total, an area of 82 acres only may be described as being suitable for agricultural purposes, and for the following reasons:

(1) An area of land amounting to 97 acres is too steep and at too high an elevation to be irrigated economically.

(2) An area of land comprising approximately 45 acres has too sandy soil to allow of profitable cultivation.

(3) An area of land amounting to 42 acres is flooded at high water by the overflow from a small lake situated on the school property immediately north of the South Thompson River. (See accompanying plan)

(4) An area of land amounting to 17 acres is occupied

KAMLOOPS INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL PROPERTY UNDER CULTIVATION

The total amount of land, the property of the Kamloops Industrial School, which is irrigated and under cultivation at the present time comprises an area of 75 acres.

PRESENT WATER SUPPLY

Water for irrigation purposes at the Industrial School is obtained at the present time by means of a 1,000 U.S. g.p.m. centrifugal pump, direct connected to one 25 H.P., 220 volt, 3 phase induction motor.

This pump, which is situated in a wooden pump house on the north bank of the South Thompson River, supplies water from the river through 340 feet of 8" diameter wood stave pipe to distribution ditches, situated as shown on the accompanying plan.

The capacity of this pump, i.e., 1,000 U.S. g.p.m., is sufficient to supply an area of 100 acres of land.

The area recommended, 362 acres, is sufficiently large to permit of a certain amount of wastage in cultivating the land, which is only to be expected in the operation of an institution of this kind.

It should also be borne in mind that, as the produce grown is produced primarily for the use of the school, a poor or blemished crop of potatoes, corn, etc., need not necessarily be lost, as would be the case if same had to be offered for sale in the open market, but may be consumed in the above institution, with no appreciable wastage.

METHODS WHEREBY AN ADDITIONAL AREA OF 80 ACRES MAY BE ACQUIRED FOR SCHOOL PURPOSES-

Four methods by which an additional area of 80 acres of land can be provided for school purposes may be considered, as follows:

(1) The purchase by the Department of 80 acres of land somewhere in the vicinity of Kamloops, outside the Indian Reserve property, and the irrigation of same by pumping or other means.

(2) The purchase or appropriation of 80 acres of land, the property of Riley and Anthony, which is
Anthony, which is situated on the Indian Reserve immediately west of the Industrial School property, and the transfer of Eley and Anthony to some other part of the reserve.

(3) The allotment of 80 acres of any vacant lands situated on the Indian Reserve to the Industrial School for farming purposes, and the irrigation of same by means of pumping, etc.

(4) To drain the lake situated on the school property and by this means to reclaim from flooding and render fit for cultivation an area of land including and immediately surrounding this lake amounting to 57 acres, 37 of which would be on school property, the remaining 20 acres being part of the Indian reserve, and to allot these 20 acres to the Industrial School.

The above proposals may be dealt with in their order, but as each proposal requires water for irrigation to be supplied by pumping, a study of the power situation in the Kamloops District and the bearing which this situation has on the supply of power for irrigation must first of all be considered.

POWER SITUATION

Power is supplied to the City of Kamloops and vicinity by a municipal hydro-electric plant situated on the Barriere River at a distance of forty miles north of the City of Kamloops.

This plant, which has a rated capacity of 2,000 H.P. is assisted during peak loads by an auxiliary steam plant having a capacity of 1,000 H.P.
1,000 H.P.

The hydro-electric plant, which has now been in use for a period of twelve years, is in very bad condition and considerable trouble is experienced each year in maintaining the water supply.

The wooden flume which carries this supply from the dam to the powerhouse has been in use longer than was originally intended, and is constantly being carried away, which necessitates the almost constant operation of the steam plant to supply the power which has already been contracted for by the city.

For this reason, the municipality has refused to enter into any further contracts for the supply of electric power for new enterprises, until such time as arrangements have been made to increase the present power supply.

At this date there does not appear to be any prospect of conditions improving for a period of at least two years.

These conditions apply most strictly to any new applications for power, but it is possible to make arrangements for a slight increase in the size of an existing plant where it can be shown that such an increase is necessary and desirable, but that increase in power will only be supplied at a rate equal to the cost of production by steam plant, i.e., $3 per Kilowatt hour in place of $1½ per Kilowatt hour, usually charged for hydro-electric power in this vicinity when supplied for pumping purposes.
PROPOSAL NO. 1 -

The purchase by the Department of 80 acres of land somewhere in the vicinity of Kamloops, and the irrigation of same by pumping.

The proposal would require the Department to purchase the land at an estimated cost of from forty to fifty dollars per acre and to provide water for irrigation by means of either a Beisel, semi-Beisel or gasoline engine, as no electric power is at present available for such an enterprise.

The first cost of these engines is high and their operation compared to electric power comparatively expensive.

Moreover, pumping by this means must still be regarded as being in the experimental stage and it is extremely doubtful if farming operations could be carried out successfully under these conditions by this institution.

The purchase of a Beisel or other type of engine and the installation of pump, pipes, flumes, etc., to irrigate a small area of 80 acres would not, in my opinion, be an economical investment, and should not be undertaken by the Department at the present time.

PROPOSAL NO. 2 -

To purchase or appropriate for school purposes 80 acres of land, the property of Eley and Anthony, situated on the Indian Reserve west of the Industrial School property, and the transfer of Eley and Anthony to some other part of the reserve.
This proposal is the one which, in my opinion, would eventually prove to be the most satisfactory.

By this means, the school would be provided with sufficient land for all agricultural requirements.

This land would be self-contained in one unit and possible of easy irrigation by means of an enlargement of the present pumping plant.

The power situation with regard to lack of power would not apply in this case, as the existing plant may be increased in size without any undue trouble.

The two Indians who are concerned in the case, Eley and Anthony, could be compensated financially by the Department for the loss of their present holdings and allotted land on some other part of the reserve where the operations which they would carry out (i.e., dry farming) would be exactly similar to those which they are practising at the present time.

PROPOSAL NO. 3.

The allotment of 80 acres of vacant land situated on the Indian Reserve to the Industrial School for farming purposes, and the irrigation of same by means of pumping.

This proposal is open to the same objections as is Proposal No. 1, i.e.,

(1) The lack of available power supply at the present time.

(2) The high first cost of installing any other type of pumping plant to serve a small area of...
area of 80 acres.

This proposal should not, in my opinion, be considered by the Department except as part of a general scheme to irrigate a large portion of the reserve.

PROPOSAL NO. 4 -

To drain the lake situated on school property and by this means to reclaim from flooding and render fit for cultivation an area of land including and immediately surrounding the lake amounting to 57 acres, 37 of which would be on school property, the remaining 20 being part of the Indian Reserve, and to allot these extra 20 acres to the Industrial School.

Proposal No. 4, which is the one most strongly recommended by the principal of the Industrial School (The Reverend Father McGuire) would necessitate the construction of two dykes, one situated on the Indian Reserve and the other on the Industrial School property. (See accompanying plan).

The total area which would be reclaimed by this method would amount to 57 acres, or 23 acres less than the extra amount required for agricultural purposes by the Industrial School.

The above project, while it has the appearance of being feasible, is nevertheless open to many objections and no definite assurance could be given by an engineer with regard to its ultimate success.

This project may now be reviewed in detail as follows:

The lake situated on the Kamloops In-

dustrial School
Industrial School property contains an area at low water of 17.5 acres and is subject to flooding at high water by the overflow from the North and South Thompson Rivers, which enters the low-lying ground on the Kamloops Indian Reserve through two channels, as shown on the accompanying plan.

These channels, while they are comparatively narrow at their entrance, are situated a considerable distance apart, and a large area of land, comprising approximately 210 acres, is flooded at high water and rendered unfit for cultivation.

A suggestion has been made that certain lands immediately surrounding and including this lake can be reclaimed by a system of dyking (see accompanying plan) and that the lands thus drained, comprising an area of 57 acres, can then be used for farming purposes by the Industrial School.

While the engineering features involved in such a project would not in themselves present any special difficulty, (entailing only the construction of two earth dykes, the installation of drain pipes, outlet valves, etc.) certain other considerations affect the situation, and a study of the rise and fall of the South Thompson River and its relation with regard to the behaviour of the lake itself is necessary before this scheme can be proceeded with.

For purposes of comparison, the elevation of ordinary low water in the South Thompson River may be taken as 0.00 and the elevation of

ordinary high water
ordinary high water may be taken as 14.00, giving an average rise of 14 feet.

The elevation of ordinary high water in the lake itself is the same as that in the South Thompson River, i.e., 14.00, but the elevation of ordinary low water in the lake is 8.00, giving an average fall of only 5 feet.

From this it will be seen that average low water in the lake remains at an elevation of 8 feet above the average low water in the South Thompson River.

That is to say, that after the water in the South Thompson River has receded or fallen below the elevation of the inlet channel, the water surface in the lake ceases to fall rapidly.

This condition of affairs would indicate that the lake bottom is impervious, i.e., will not be affected by sub-surface seepage after it has been drained.

This indication, however, cannot be taken as final, for test pits dug in the surrounding ground show that the soil surrounding this lake between the lake shore and the river bank and situated between low water elevation of the lake, 8.00, and high water elevation, 14.00, to be composed of a porous mixture of alluvial silt, i.e., sand, gravel and other sediment, which would not give the appearance of being water-tight.

It is quite possible, therefore, that after the dykes had been constructed, water might find its way through some underlying porous strata situated between and connecting the lake with the river shore, and render useless the reclamation work which had been carried out; or in any event make it necessary.
make it necessary for drainage by pumping to be resorted to during the high water period.

While it is my opinion that this work if undertaken would prove satisfactory and no great amount of seepage would occur, as stated previously in this report, the condition of affairs is such that no engineer should be asked to give a definite assurance that the project would be a success, and any reclamation of this land by the methods proposed should be regarded by the Department in the nature of an experiment, and due allowance made for a possible loss.

Another feature which would have to be taken into consideration is that the average elevation of the surface of the river bank along the north shore of the South Thompson River is 18.00 and that the elevation of ordinary high water in the South Thompson River is 14.00, a difference of only 4 feet.

Should we therefore experience at any time in the future a year of extreme high water (i.e., a rise of 5 feet above ordinary high water) such as has been experienced in the past, the water would overflow the banks in spite of any dykes which might have been constructed.

As these banks in the vicinity of the lake are extremely narrow, this flooding would undoubtedly result in other and larger channels being cut in them and these channels would require to be dyked again after the high water had receded, which would necessitate additional expenditure.

An examination of the accompanying plan will show that
will show that the logical method of reclaiming this land, if reclamation is going to be carried out, would be to dyke both channels, one dyke being situated near the east bank of the North Thompson River in the immediate vicinity of the Canadian National Railway right-of-way, the other being situated at the channel immediately south of the present lake.

Unfortunately, no water for irrigation purposes is available for this part of the Indian reserve, and the Indians therefore depend upon the flooding of these lands in the spring for the raising of hay during the summer, and any suggestion which includes the installation of dykes near the Canadian National Railway or the closing of the culverts situated beneath the public highway has to date met with strong opposition from them, and for this reason has not been considered further.

COST OF PROPOSAL NO. 4 -

The cost of constructing two dykes as outlined in Proposal No. 4 (see accompanying plan) and the installation of drainage ditches, pipes, outlet valves, etc., would amount to $3,000.00, but this amount would be considerably exceeded should it be found after the dykes had been constructed that sub-surface seepage existed; for it would then be necessary to provide pumps for drainage purposes during the high water period, and the size of these pumps and their cost would depend upon the amount of water which it would be necessary to handle.

REMARKS RE PROPOSAL NO. 4 -

In view of the above conditions, it is my opinion that
my opinion that Proposal No. 4 contains a certain element of risk with regard to possible sub-surface seepage; and while this element of risk should not be overrated, it would be well to give it due consideration, together with the possible expense which might be incurred should a year of extremely high water be experienced in the future, and the north bank of the South Thompson River be flooded, thus forming new channels between the river and the lake.

In addition to the above, the area which would be reclaimed by this means would amount in all to 57 acres and the estimated expenditure would be $3,000.00, equal to a net charge of over fifty dollars per acre, which amount does not include the expenditure necessary to provide water for irrigation purposes on this area.

For these reasons I would not recommend that this project be proceeded with unless it is considered by the Department to be the only one which would prove satisfactory to them.

RECOMMENDATION-

After careful consideration of the existing conditions, I would hereby recommend that Proposal No.2 as outlined in this report be adopted by the Department, and that the two Indians concerned, Eley and Anthony, be compensated for their loss and transferred to some other part of the reserve, and that their present holdings be allotted to the Kamloops Industrial School for use by that institution.

Should the Department
Should the Department, however, consider this arrangement to be unsatisfactory, I would respectfully recommend that the whole situation be allowed to remain in abeyance until additional electric power is available for pumping purposes in this vicinity, or until such time as some other portion of the reserve is placed under irrigation when additional land can then be provided for school use.

In addition to the above, I would also recommend that arrangements have now been entered into by the Kamloops Industrial School whereby additional land is leased from the Indians for agricultural purposes at this institution, thus making the total area of land available for cultivation 162 acres instead of 82 acres (school property), that the present pumping plant, which has a capacity of 1,000 U.S. G.P.M. only, be replaced by a pumping unit having a capacity of 2,000 U.S. G.P.M. at an estimated cost of $3,540.00, and that this work be carried out immediately in order that sufficient water for irrigation purposes may be available during the coming season. (See Appendix "A").

Dear Sir:

Having reference to the matter of increasing the pumping capacity at the Kemloops Indian School in order that an area of land comprising 80 acres, which Reverend Principal McGuire has leased from Chief Eli Larue and an Indian named Anthony, may be brought under irrigation, I beg to say that I have received from District Chief Engineer Webb, of the Dominion Water Power Branch, a very comprehensive report of Engineer Tredcroft on this subject. I expect by this time you will also have received a copy of this report from which you will observe the Engineer has gone into the matter from several different angles and has set forth four different proposals as hereunder.

1. The purchase by the Department of 80 acres of land somewhere near Kamloops (apparently outside the Reserve) and irrigating the same by pumping.

2. The purchase or expropriation of the 80 acres of land which the Rev. Principal already has under lease from the Indians above named, which land adjoins the Kemloops School allotment.

3. The purchase of 80 acres of land in some other portion of the Reserve.

4. To reclaim 57 acres of land at present covered by a small lake, 37 acres of which are on the School allotment and 20 acres on the Reserve proper.

Of the four proposals, Engineer Tredcroft has given extremely good reasons why No. 2 is the most practical and economical at the present time, and I most certainly concur with him in his conclusions, except to say that it may be doubtful if the Department can afford to purchase the 80 acres of leased land at the present time. It would, however, be much more satisfactory to ultimately purchase this land outright.

To carry out this proposal it will involve the

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
installation of a pump having a capacity of 2,000 U.S. g.p.m. to replace the present one which has a capacity of 1,000 U.S. g.p.m., which together with the necessary amount of wood stave pipe, other materials, labour, freight charges, etc. will cost $3,540.00. As against this amount, the Engineer estimates that $850.00 may be obtained by the Department for the pumping plant already in use.

I would recommend, therefore, that proposal No. 2 be adopted and acted upon. As the expenditure to be created is in connection with the Kamloops Residential School, the charge should be against the Indian Education Vote, and if there are funds now available from this source, it would be most desirable to authorize the Dominion Water Power Branch to purchase the machinery and material before the end of the present month. The work of installation could then be taken in hand during April and May, and the land would be ready for irrigation early in June. This point, I think, is important in view of the fact that it is predicted that we are going to have a very dry summer in the irrigation districts, due to the lack of rain and snow during the winter and, consequently, there being little moisture in the ground.

With regard to obtaining a water licence for this School, I now beg to inform you that application has been filed with the Comptroller of Water Rights for 500 acre feet of water for the Kamloops School to be pumped from the South Thompson River. Father is working his (Anthony's) place on terms agreed upon between them both. Principal are amicable. Should the feelings between them change at any future date, Anthony may cease to work at the school, and would then require his own place. Dear Doctor,

I am writing to make a suggestion concerning the letter dated March 25, 1926.

Let me begin by saying to you, who understand, instead of to others who might not, that if the land and improvements of Anthony Larue are taken for the school without first making proper provision for him, myself and the school will receive a blow from which we will never recover. Anthony cares little; he works hard; he stands for me; he stands for the school; he stands for the Department. He is a tower of strength for you and for me. Indian people, who fought him and his policy, which was inspired by me, of remaining at school, now come to him for advice.

Anthony will do anything for you or for me. In substance, he has said to me repeatedly: "Father, I don't care what land I have as long as it is under your ditch."

Chief Eley Larue and Mrs. Leonard are uncle and aunt respectively to Anthony. The latter has twelve acres lying West of Eley's land and under our ditch and which like Eley's land is lying idle owing to lack of water.

My suggestion is: Either take those twelve acres and Eley's for the school and leave...
Anthony entirely alone; or, take Anthony's and Eley's for the school and give Anthony the twelve acres belonging to Mrs. Leonard and the eight acres off the West part of Eley's. The second alternative would entail the building of a house and digging of a well in lieu of those he would lose. If you supplied the material the school management would be responsible for the labor.

You can see the importance of dealing first and fairly with Anthony. Better by far for me to lose eight acres than to lose Anthony, good will and that of the Indian people.

Trusting that you will give me protection in this matter,

I remain,
Very truly yours,

The sewage system was designed to take care of a flow of
of a flow of sewage amounting to 10,000 U. S. gallons per day, or 40 U. S. gallons per capita per diem; this amount being equal to the average daily consumption of water per head in institutions of this kind. It is what is known as the septic tank sub-surface irrigation system, and consists of a reinforced concrete septic tank connected by means of a sewer pipe with two disposal beds composed of 4" diameter open-jointed land tile, laid 3'6" below the surface of the ground. The original intention was to lay this land tile at a depth of 18" only below the surface to provide better aeration of the soil, but the nature of the ground was found after excavation had been commenced to be such that a greater depth was considered necessary.

SEPTIC TANK -

The septic tank, which is constructed of reinforced concrete, is situated at a depth of 3 feet below the surface of the ground to avoid danger of freezing. It is divided by a wall into two compartments, one called a settling chamber, which is the septic part of the tank, and the other called a siphon chamber, in which the effluent is collected and intermittently discharged to the disposal beds.

The settling chamber is of the following dimensions: 15' x 7' x 9'6" deep, and is connected by means of a 3 foot overflow weir with the siphon chamber having the following dimensions: 15' x 7' x 6'6" deep. This siphon chamber is equipped with an automatic siphon which discharges when the effluent in the chamber reaches a depth of 3'6"; and therefore discharges four times a day under normal load.

The settling
The settling chamber has a capacity of 5,900 U.S. gallons, equal to 13 hours flow, and the detention period is therefore 13 hours, with a rate of flow through the chamber of 6" per hour.

Drains have been provided in each chamber to permit of the tank being emptied and cleaned when required.

Vent pipes, manholes, ladders, overflow pipe, etc., have been provided and arranged as shown on the accompanying plan.

**SEWER PIPES**

The sewage is carried from the school by means of four 4" diameter vitrified sewer pipes to the main inspection chamber which is situated 85 feet from the school. From this point it is transferred by means of one 8" diameter sewer pipe to the septic tank. On each of the two outside sewer lines additional concrete inspection chambers have been installed, close to the school building, to provide against a possible stoppage in the pipes at this point. (See accompanying plan).

**INSPECTION CHAMBER**

The main inspection chamber is of reinforced concrete and so placed that it is equi-distant between the school and septic tank. All pipes entering this chamber are laid on straight lines and even grades to allow of easy cleaning should the pipes at any time become clogged.

**DISCHARGE PIPE**

The discharge pipe from the septic tank to the disposal beds is 6" diameter vitrified sewer pipe, 210 feet in length.
210 feet in length, laid to a grade of .005 and is straight and free from bends. It is called upon to discharge approximately 2500 U.S. gallons every four hours and is large enough to ensure the effluent reaching the farthest part of the disposal beds, thus avoiding oversaturation of the ground at any place.

**DISPOSAL BEDS**

The disposal beds, which are two in number, consist of 4" diameter land tile laid to conform with the contours of the ground on a grade of .003 and 3'6" below the surface of the ground.

The east bed consists of 2,000 lineal feet of land tile, while the west bed comprises 1,500 lineal feet. (See accompanying plan.) These two amounts in all make a total length of 3,500 lineal feet, which amount is less than it was originally proposed, the reason being that the excellent nature of the ground which was encountered at a depth of 3'6" made it unnecessary to install the full amount.

**CONSTRUCTION**

Construction of the above plant was carried out by contract under the supervision of this office, the contractors for the plant being The Kamloops Plumbing and Heating Company of Kamloops, B.C., and the time occupied in completing the work amounted in all to a total of 77 working days.

**COST**

The total cost of the above project amounted to $3,313.28, whereas the original estimate called for an expenditure of $3,700.00

**REMARKS**

The above work was carried out during the months of
months of October, November and December, 1924, and has at this date been in constant use for a period of 12 months, during which time it has apparently given every satisfaction.

INTRODUCTION-

Sir:-

In accordance with instructions contained in your telegram of the 15th ultimo, I visited the Kamloops Industrial School and carried out an investigation having reference to the unsatisfactory operation of the drainage system which was provided in the new building to take care of the drainage water from the laundry, and in this connection I would report to you as follows:

PRESENT SYSTEM-

Disposal of the drainage water from the laundry at the Kamloops Industrial School is carried out at the present time by means of a drainage pit.
a drainage pit situated on the west bank of the South Thompson River in close proximity to the school buildings (see accompanying plan), and which is connected with the laundry by means of a 4" diameter drain pipe.

The drainage pit, which has the following dimensions: 6' x 4' x 4' deep, is situated at a depth of 4' below the surface of the ground, and is of concrete construction, with the exception of the roof, which is composed of 4" x 6" timbers.

METHOD OF OPERATION-

Drainage water which gathers in the drainage gutter situated in the laundry itself is transferred by means of the 4" drainage pipe to the drainage pit, in which compartment it is permitted to stand until such time as dissipation takes place by seepage.

REASONS FOR OPERATION-

1. Owing to the high concentration of soap which is present in this water after it has been used in the various washing machines, satisfactory operation of the drainage pit is prevented after a short time through the surface of the ground in the pit becoming covered with a film of soap which effectually prevents further seepage.

When this occurs, the pit becomes filled with stagnant water which rises to the surface and, percolating through the ground, overflows into the South Thompson River in the immediate vicinity of the intake of the school domestic water supply.
water supply and at a short distance above the intake of the City of Kamloops water works.

2. No method was provided by the designer whereby the drainage pit could be cleaned other than by removing the 4' of earth situated on the top of this pit and emptying same by means of buckets.

3. The drainage pit is situated in a light clay soil which is unsuitable for good drainage.

4. The pit is situated within 50' of the west bank of the South Thompson River, which distance is less than that which is required by the various health regulations relating to the pollution of streams, and, as stated above, is in close vicinity to the intake of the domestic water supply for the school.

GENERAL REMARKS RE HANDLING OF LAUNDRY WATER:

Waste water containing a high concentration of soap, as in the present instance, is extremely difficult to handle by sub-surface drainage.

Any drainage pit which might be provided would require to be constantly cleaned at short intervals, the nature of the water being such that after a short period of use the ground through which seepage ordinarily takes place becomes covered with soap which penetrates as much as 6" below the surface of the ground, thus preventing a satisfactory run-off.

When this condition of affairs occurs during the winter months while the ground outside is frozen and covered to a depth of from one to three
one to three feet with snow, it is extremely difficult to provide a way whereby this water can be disposed of, and for this reason it would, in my opinion, be wise to abandon the sub-surface method of disposal and handle this drainage water by a system of surface irrigation, i.e., to transfer this water to some part of the Industrial School property at a safe distance from the school buildings so that it will not prove injurious to health or become unsightly and where it may be applied to land that is continuously under cultivation and which is being ploughed, harrowed, etc., regularly.

This method is the one that is most usually adopted for waters carrying a high percentage of soaps, fats, etc.

A system of the proposed type, i.e., surface drainage, would cost but little more than the installation of additional and larger drainage pits and will require practically no attention.

This system will operate equally well during the winter as during the summer months, and if properly installed will be free from bad odours, will not become unsightly and will in no way affect the agricultural value of the land to which the water is applied, as the soap under such conditions acts only as a fertiliser.

For the above reasons I would hereby recommend that a system of surface irrigation be installed as outlined below.

DESCRIPTION-

That a concrete drainage pit having the following
the following inside dimensions: 5' x 5' x 6',
be constructed below the school laundry immediately beneath the present floor and that this pit be connected by means of a 3" diameter drain pipe with the present drainage gutter situated in the laundry.

Waste water which will collect in this pit can then be handled by means of a small electrically-operated, submerged type sump pump which will deliver this waste water through 200 lineal feet of wood stove pipe to a point situated on the high ground in front of the school buildings and marked "A" on the accompanying plan.

From this point the water will be conducted by gravity through 420 lineal feet of 4" diameter drain tile and used for irrigation purposes on the school garden.

The pump, which will operate against a total head of 28', will have a capacity of 20 U.S. g.p.m., and will be controlled automatically by means of a float situated in the well and will commence and cease operation when the water in the well reaches a certain height.

Both the discharge pipe and the land tile will be buried at a depth of 2' below the surface of the ground in order that they may not become unsightly after long use.

COST-

The cost of the above system, including purchase of machinery, construction of concrete drainage pit and installation of discharge pipe and drain tile, etc., will amount to $425.00.
COST OF OPERATION-

The cost of power for operation of the above disposal plant, assuming 2,000 U.S. Gallons of laundry water to be handled each week, with power supplied at 1½ per Kilowatt hour, will amount to approximately 6½ per month.

RECOMMENDATION-

After a careful study of conditions at the Kamloops Industrial School, I would hereby recommend that a disposal system by pumping as outlined in this report be installed as soon as possible to take care of the waste water resulting from laundry operations at the above institution.

You will note that there is a total suction lift approximately 24' at extreme low water.

While all well designed centrifugal pumps will draw water by suction a vertical distance of 24', and even more, we have found from long experience that it is not good practice to operate centrifugal pumps under extreme suction lifts, if it can be avoided. We would suggest that if possible at all the pump should be set at a lower elevation, preferably at a point so that the suction lift cannot exceed 18' to 20'.

This would put the floor of the pump-house below high water elevation, but the floor and walls of the pump-house could be made of concrete, and the walls raised high enough so that water could not enter under extreme high water conditions.

We believe this added expense would be many times paid for by the more satisfactory operation of the pump. We are most anxious to have the pump give utmost satisfaction, and what we have said applies to all centrifugal pumps, regardless of design or make.

You will note also that there is a friction loss of 2.35' in the 10" foot valve. This amounts to almost

Dear Doctor:

Some time ago we asked you to give us some three or four acres of the Indian Reserve West of the little lake on our property which would enable us to drain the lake.

The Water Power Branch has no doubt given you a report.... It is a thing of which they cannot be very certain. The lake may have a little spring in the bottom...... And the cost of drainage?..... We have discussed it here several times. This is no criticism of their work or report.

Apart from all that, we present a request. Let us drain the lake, which means to block up the inlet from the river and build a dyke on the West - both of which operations would be on land occupied by the Reserve.

1. Corn land is low lying land. We have little of it; even the land we rent from the Chief is not corn land. It is something we need and there are twenty acres in it.

2. At present we get nothing from it save a little pasture at low water. Neither do the Indians except probably a ton or two of marsh hay at best.

3. By taking this land we do little or no harm to the Indian people.

4. The cost of draining, or trying to drain the lake, is labor and labor in our long suit. If we
fail, we lose our labor. We might ask you for a few tiles or a little cement, but the expense would be trifling. Labor is the real cost.

If you could find your way clear to grant us this request during the present month, we would try to be ready for the high waters next June.

Yours very truly,

James McCreery

October 13, 1926.

Dear Dr. Scott:

I beg to enclose a letter from Rev. Father McGuire, Principal of the Kamloops Residential School, which is addressed to you and forwarded through me.

In connection with this matter, I have made careful investigation of the ground, in company with Mr. E.H. Tredcroft, and I have to say that I am quite in favour of the matter, having in view the fact that Father McGuire's letter apparently means that he himself is willing to supply the labour. If you will look at the report made by Mr. Tredcroft upon additional land for the Kamloops School, you will find this scheme mentioned as number 4. In this report, Mr. Tredcroft states that the scheme will cost $3000.00, but on questioning him I find that this was somewhat of a rough estimate, and that the principal cost would be labour. Mr. Tredcroft's idea also included a concrete dam, and I must say that in this I do not agree with the necessity of concrete. The river banks are earth, and are well reinforced with growth of willow and big timber, and I cannot see any reason, nor does past history show any signs of serious erosion. The inlet from the river is, to my mind, an ideal situation for the placing of an earth dam. It is very narrow and the dam can be set well back from the river bank, and if planted with willow, it would appear to me as though it would be equally as strong as the remainder of the bank. I cannot really see any reason for making one part stronger than another, which would be done if concrete works were put in.

My opinion is that if as little expenditure as possible were made by the Department for materials, and then if by any possibility it did not work, it would be very little loss. In fact, in case of piping for an outlet, it might be found that none is necessary and the piping could be used elsewhere.

I quite agree with Father McGuire that it seems to be a great pity to allow all this good land to be practically wasted when the odds are, and Mr. Tredcroft agrees, that with drainage the land could be successfully reclaimed.

Of course it would be necessary to make some arrangements about additional land which does not belong to the school, but I do not think there would be any difficulty about arranging for this, as it is not used by the Indians anyway.

My further reason for recommending this is because it will save all kinds of trouble in trying to get other lands for the School from the Indians, and also because this site is much closer to the school than any other land would be.

Dr. Duncan G. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.
I should advise that the Rev. Principal be informed that if he will supply and supervise all the necessary labour for embankment work, that piping, head gate material, etc., up to say, $500.00 will be supplied him by the Department, as the material is required, and ask him for a rough estimate as to what he does require. I should suggest that he be allowed to do this work entirely on his own.

I really think that this work is such as could be undertaken by any ordinary farmer, and is hardly an engineering problem. Of course, he could, if necessary, get Mr. Tredoroff to run any levels or do anything technical, that is required.

By allowing Father McGuire to undertake this work himself, he is really the man who is running the risk, if there is any, and the Department would only be risking the probably slight cost of material.

Yours very truly,

I have your letter of the 13th instant, enclosing a communication from the Rev. Principal of the Kamloops Indian Residential School. I note that it is proposed to reclaim 57 acres of land, at present covered by the small lake immediately southwest of the school - 37 acres of which are on the school allotment and 20 acres on the Indian reserve. As this scheme has been favourably reported on by the Dominion Water Power Engineer and as the cost to the Department would be not more than $600, I am quite favourably disposed. The Rev. Principal must consider it worthy of trial, or he would not be willing to supply all the labour.

With a view to proceeding with the activity, please arrange to have the Indian Band in Council release for school purposes the 20 acres which is on Reserve No. 1. You may then authorize Father McGuire to commence the work, which should be under your supervision whenever possible. If materials are required, they should be purchased by either you or Mr. Indian Agent Helmsing, after securing competitive prices.

Yours very truly,

November 4, 1926.

Dear Sir:

On the morning of this date, at the earnest request of Rev. Father McGuire, Principal of the Kamloops Residential School, I went over to look into some sanitary arrangements which are out of order.

As a preliminary, I might say that three of the children and one of the Sisters at the School are down with dysentery. The Rev. Principal, and, naturally, both the Agent and myself are anxious that no epidemic should break out in the school owing to neglect on our part.

It seems that the dirty water from the wash house and laundry runs into a small concrete tank, which has seepage pipes in it. Theoretically, this water is supposed to seep away through the sand but practically, it does not do so, and the water now overflows, and has done for many months, into a trench dug by the school authorities, in the hope that it would then seep away through the sand and gravel. However, this does not work, and at the present moment there is a very large pool of this dirty water which has run down quite close to the river bank, and appears to have overflowed the temporary banking made to contain it, and gone down into the river.

In connection with the fact that this water now flows into this river, I beg to draw your attention to the two following facts:

1. This is illegal, as it is against the Municipal Regulations of Kamloops, being only a few hundred yards above the intake for the water supply of the town.

2. The intake for the school drinking water is only about 100 feet above where this overflow has taken place down the river bank, and as it is situated in the bend of the river, it so happens that there is a back-water there, and both the Principal and myself are afraid that this is or may contaminate the drinking water.

Instructions have been issued by myself and the medical men to the Principal to have a sample of the water analysed immediately.

Several months ago, I understand, this matter was brought to the attention of the Indian Department, and a suggestion to rectify it made by Mr. Tredcroft, Department of Water Rights Engineer, which suggestion was submitted. The medical men also state that this overflow from the laundries is not only dangerous from the point of view that it may contaminate the drinking water, but it is also dangerous lying around in stale pools as it is right now, just beside the schoolhouse.

Dr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent-General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the contents of Inspector Pragnell's letter to you, dated Nov. 4th, concerning the present condition of the drainage system from the laundry of the Kamloops Indian Residential School, I beg to say that the above mentioned conditions were reported to this Department on the 11th of March of this year by Agent Helmsing. On the same date I requested the local office of the Dominion Water Power Branch by telephone to have the matter investigated. This request was confirmed by letter on the 13th of March, turned out hereunder. On April 23rd a report was sent in recommending that the present underground disposal system be replaced by a pumping outfit and underground pipe line, by which the waste water would be removed some 200 ft. from the School. From this point it is suggested that the water be conducted by gravity through 420 lineal feet of four inch drain tile, and used for irrigation purposes on the school garden. The pump will be automatically operated by electricity and the total cost of the system, including the machinery, construction of concrete drainage pit, and the installation of discharge pipe, drain tile, etc., will amount to $425.00. The cost of operation will only amount to about six cents per month. The present system has been in operation for a long time, and is reported to be entirely inadequate to meet the requirements of such an institution. Dear Sir:

I would like to call your attention to cases of dysentery which have been developing in the Industrial School here. So far there are three cases in the Hospital and there are several others, seven at least, in the School.

In company with Father McQuire and yourself, I went over the sanitary arrangements at the Industrial School and find as follows:

There are a number of outside closets, which are being used by the boys of the School. While these are as well taken care of as outside closets usually are, yet they are, through the breeding of flies, a very great menace to the health of the Institution. I went through the dining room and kitchen of the School and found a large number of flies. In an institution of this kind, it is very difficult to keep these pests out of the building, but it is the fact of outside sources of contamination that makes them dangerous.

Besides the outside closets, there is a cesspool, which receives the water from the laundry. The soil about the cesspit has become completely saturated and the cesspool is constantly overflowing. This adds greatly to the other sources of infection.

As Health Officer to the School, I would urge you as Inspector to bring these matters before the Department at Ottawa and urge that immediate steps be taken to have them remedied; otherwise the Health Department will have to consider very radical measures with regard to the School. I might add that three, at least, of these children are very seriously ill and there is a grave doubt that they will recover. Your earnest and immediate attention to this matter is of the utmost urgency.

Yours sincerely,

MGA/EM

P.S.

Referring to the overflowing cesspit, I might add that it is very close to the bank of the river and the intake for the City water supply is four or five hundred yards directly below.

November 6, 1926.

Dear Dr. Scott:

Following mine of the 4th inst., with reference to the unsanitary conditions at Kamloops Industrial School, I have to report that, yesterday, I accompanied Dr. Archibald, Medical Health Officer for the City of Kamloops, to the School. I beg to enclose the original of his letter to me.

After our examination, we came to the conclusion that the cause of this dysentry is from flies breeding in the outside closets, or on pools of water from the laundry. We do not think that contamination has actually taken place in the water that is overflowing from this laundry waste into the river, but at the same time our conclusion is that this is also a grave possibility, and should be looked into immediately. The conclusions we arrived at, therefore, bear out my special report to you regarding school accommodation, and the necessity of putting up the Boys' Wing as quickly as possible.

As you will see, in the last paragraph of the doctor's letter, three of these children are very seriously ill, and there is grave doubt of their recovery. This is a very serious state of affairs, as you can readily gather, though I do not think that any blame is attachable to the Principal of the School, as things are kept as well as they can be under the present conditions, but as you know it is almost impossible to keep outside closets sanitary, even though much chloride of lime is used. In addition, he cannot help this overflow from the laundry, as the washing must, of necessity be done.

I might point out that in the doctor's postscript, with reference to the overflowing cesspit, he means the cesspit that is used for laundry water, and not for the lavatories.

Yours very truly,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Colonel Pragnell,

I wish to acknowledge the receipt of your communications, dated November 4 and 6, advising me of the defective condition of the drainage system from the laundry at the Kamloops Indian Industrial School, B.C., also, Dr. Archibald's report of November 5, concerning the development of a number of dysentery cases amongst the pupils of this institution, resulting probably from the manner of disposal of the above mentioned drainage water.
