I might say that the work may be entrusted to one of the local engineers of the Dominion Water Power Branch whose services has been secured through the authority of the head office in Ottawa.

I have noticed your recommendation regarding the advisability of providing in the near future, additional accommodation for this school, also the necessity of erecting a new wing for the male pupils. I shall give these matters my earnest consideration as early as possible.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of October 25th, 1926, with reference to the reclamation of 30 acres of land for the use of Kamloops Residential School.

In answer to your query with reference to the letter that you mention, I have to say that no further report was forwarded by me on the matter for the reason that up to about a couple of months ago, the Rev. Principal seemed somewhat in doubt as to whether he wanted the scheme completed or not.

The real hitch, as I pointed out to Rev. Father McGuire at the time, was that the Indians would not relinquish the said twenty acres, and I asked him to try and see what he could do himself in the matter, as he was the party interested.

I heard nothing further in the matter, and now that Rev. Father McGuire has left the School, I do not for a moment think that the new Principal, Rev. Father Duplanil, will want to reclaim more land for the School. I am of the belief that his attitude is that so much land is not required and cannot be worked without sacrificing the education of the boys. His contention is that to keep a herd of cattle going is a costly business, and that, apparently the agricultural land available is quite sufficient to raise ordinary crops for school use, and fodder crops for the milk herd.

Dear Sir:

I have to report that the pump for the laundry waste at Kamloops Residential School broke down suddenly yesterday. The Principal reported the matter to me, and as it was important that the said pump be in working order by next Monday, I called on Fernie and Co., electricians, to deal with the matter, and they have sent fresh parts from the makers at Vancouver.

I went over this morning to see what was wrong, but the matter was too technical for me to deal with, so I approached the Dominion Water Power Branch who installed the pump, and asked that one of them go over there this afternoon to try to ascertain what was the cause of the break-down.

The Reverend Principal does not think that he should have to bear the whole cost of the break-down, and as the pump was only put in about a year ago, I think his contention has much in its favour. You will probably hear from him upon the matter, and if you wish me to, I can ask the Dominion Water Power Engineers to submit a report.

In connection with the various pumps and motors over at the school, I am of the opinion, and so is the Principal, that a regular monthly or two-monthly inspection of the nine motors in use should be undertaken by a proper electrician, who would be able to report as to whether these machines are kept in order, and that would perhaps save such break-downs as above mentioned. I think that for a fee, one of the local electricians would undertake the job of a regular inspection.

I have further to report that apparently there is something wrong with the volume of water pumped from the river for domestic purposes. The engines and motors of the pump seem to have the capacity, but somehow or other the water does not seem to be coming and nobody seems to have any data as to the form of intake that was put in fifteen or twenty years ago. There may be something wrong with this intake, and I have asked the Dominion Water Power Engineers to also look into this matter and report to me, so that if there is anything wrong they can recommend what should be done.

Yours truly,

Dear sir:-

Further to our conversation re the damage to water disposal pump at the Indian school, Kamloops, B. C.

Extent of Damage:

All bearings worn.
Shaft badly worn at all bearing points.
Shaft broken at coupling.
Impeller slightly scraped.
Thrust collar badly worn.
Motor entirely burned up.

This trouble was apparently due to the fact that the centre bearings on the vertical drive shaft not being greased.

It would appear that this bearing had been neglected from the original installation, as the top bearing and motor were well greased.

The bearings and the thrust collar were so badly worn and the shaft so much out of alignment, that the motor locked and burned up.

We shipped the entire pump to the manufacturer in Vancouver for repairs and expect it back in the course of a few days.

We would advise that we are making a proposition to the principal of the School to give a monthly inspection of all electrical and pump equipment, which should eliminate a further occurrence of this nature.

Yours truly, FERNIE BROS., per H. Fernie.
Sir:-

Re Sump Pump & Domestic Water Supply Pump, Kamloops Industrial School.

At the request of Colonel Pragnell, I visited the Kamloops Industrial school for the purpose of inspecting the sump pump, whose bearings had been burned out.

On inspecting the various parts of the pump I found that the top of the brass shaft had been worn half through for a length of two inches. Also at another point on the shaft, halfway down, where there was a bearing, the shaft was badly worn.

It appears that no grease had been applied to these bearings since the original installation, as there was no grease in the feed pipe for some inches from the end.

The pump and motor had been completely dismantled when I visited the school.

The runners in the pump were badly worn at the tips, due, no doubt, to the bearings being

Several schemes were considered and the leasing of Chief Eli Larue's property was decided upon. At the time it was recommended that the permanent acquisition of this parcel for school purposes be considered in 1935, when the lease expired. In 1926, approximately $4,000 was expended increasing the capacity and efficiency of the irrigation system. I understand that there is in the vicinity of the school little arable land that can be irrigated, and very careful consideration should be given before this parcel is lost to the school for even a period of five years. Please discuss this carefully with Rev. Father Duplanil and let me have a further recommendation.

Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th instant in reference to the leasing of the portion of land of Chief Eli Larue formerly leased by the Kamloops Industrial School.

I have carefully noted your remarks, also discussed the matter over again with the Rev. Principal of the School. He is of the same opinion as he was before that he does not need this land for his school at any rate for some years to come as the school has more land of their own then they are now using. He further claims that he has lost money on the Chief's leased land the last two years and from the appearance of the crops, I noticed on the place I fully agree with the Rev. Principal that he must have lost money on the land.

I carefully looked into the whole affair before I recommended to the Department that the lease should be abandoned by the school and granted to Mr. King.

There are several reasons for this I know that the former principal's idea was to keep a lot of range cattle and get hay where ever he could, he, on many occasions, I am informed, used the boys, pupils of the school, at various distances away from the school to put up the hay. The Indian parents strongly objected to this and it is possible that if the practice had been continued to this date that we would have more of our school buildings empty. The present Principal's idea is to run a good school where the pupils are getting as much education as possible under the circumstances and have the pupils in the class rooms as much as possible instead of running about the country chasing cattle and putting up hay. Then again the present principal informs me that he has more land now belonging to the school than he has under cultivation he has no range for cattle and he feels that if and as long as he has land enough to raise hay enough for his miling cows and to grow enough vegetables that he has enough, both the principal and myself also agreed that Chief Eli Larue is much better off getting the present offered rental than the $240.00 per annum which he was getting from the school.

I think that covers the situation fully at this time, if it is favored after five years that the lease should not be renewed the matter could then be dealt with.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(Ewen MacLeod)

Dear Mr. MacLeod,

Will you be kind enough to bring to the attention of the Dept. the work which has been done here at the Kamloops Indian Residential School to improve and beautify the grounds. I do not speak of the grading. It did cost me a great deal more than I expected. It was my own mistake; it is my own loss. I am speaking of other improvements, viz., the tearing down of old buildings, the levelling of a hill back of the school for playground, the building of an implement shed and of a garage, the building of storage room for storm windows, etc. You remember the old approach to the school buildings. Most unsightly.

Compare with the present appearance. The City of Kamloops and the Provincial Govt. were kind enough to help us and to lend us wheel scrapers and other tools. To finish to work properly I needed a grader which I bought at a cost of $175.00.

In buying this grader, I had in mind not only the ground but the children. We must keep the road between Kamloops and the School open winter and summer. We never know when the Doctor will be needed, we never know when a child will need the Doctor, the Clinic and the Hospital. The grader will help us in keeping the road clear no matter how much wind comes.

The grader will also help us to put under proper cultivation some ten or twelve acres of land. At present we cannot irrigate some portion of the school property. By grading the land it will be easily irrigated and therefore properly cultivated.

Will you be kind enough to recommend to the Dept. that the purchase of the grader be approved and that compensation be given me. A new grader costs $300.00 plus freight. I paid $175.00.

With best wishes, I remain,

Ottawa, May 21st, 1931.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of February 18th, last, with reference to the land appurtenant to the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

A careful search has been made of our records for information concerning the property which the residential school was entitled to in the Kamloops Indian Reserve. No definite information can be obtained regarding this land other than that, in 1886, a parcel purporting to contain about 160 acres was recorded by Indian Superintendent Vowell. This property was owned by a woman known as Widow Lemieux who, at the time payment was made to her in 1889 for her improvements on this property, was known as Mary Kliklekhkan having married the Kamloops Chief Louis Kliklekhkan in February, 1889. Payment of $165.00 was made to her in March of that year.

A sketch showing the property to be acquired was forwarded to the Department on July 30th, 1888. Comparison of this sketch with the plan accompanying your letter of December 19th, last, would make it appear that, at some subsequent time, a survey had been made and the corners posted of a parcel containing 320 acres. This parcel shows an additional length of land along the north and east of the property, although the S.W. corner apparently coincides with the S.W. corner of the parcel obtained from Widow Lemieux. However, the original westerly boundary was only 16 chains and this tracing plan shows an additional length of nearly 37 chains to this boundary. The northerly boundary was originally 105 chains and this later plan shows it to be 11 chains longer. The easterly boundary was originally 11 chains and the later plan shows an additional 5 chains.

As mentioned above, a careful search of our records does not show when or by whom this later survey was made nor does it show that any definite arrangements were made to increase the school property to 320 acres.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Dear Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your 154-6-9 of May 21st last, with reference to the lands appurtenant to Kamloops Indian Residential School.

It appears to me that every possible source of information has been exhausted in connection with the matter, and that it cannot be shown that any one was authorized to enlarge the grounds to 320 acres, nor that there was any authorized survey made of the original land under the Widow LeRoux purchase in 1888, which was purported to contain 160 acres.

The School Principals have placed new lands under cultivation in recent years—in fact they have practically all the land under cultivation now that can be brought under the present pumping system.

I would therefore recommend that the lands at present under cultivation be surveyed by a duly qualified engineer, commencing at the southwest corner of the Widow LeRoux parcel, thence north a sufficient number of chains to cover the lands under cultivation, thence east to cover the lands under cultivation, thence south to the South Thompson River.

This may be found to contain more or less than the original 160 acres intended to have been set aside in 1888. However, in discussing the situation with the principal men of the Kamloops Band of Indians, I find that this would be satisfactory to them.

I cannot see where the School Management could have any serious objection, as the lands outside the cultivated lands are steep, rough hillsides, and whilst we are dealing with the question, we might as well finish it in proper order. All of which is respectfully submitted.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum

Deputy Minister,

In 1888 a parcel of 160 acres in the Kamloops Indian reserve was acquired from the Indian holder for school purposes. Later correspondence refers to this parcel, which is now occupied by the Kamloops Indian residential school, as 283 acres. There is on file a plan of a parcel containing 320 acres and although the S.W. corner of this parcel apparently coincides with the S.W. corner of the parcel obtained from the Indian owner in 1888, it increases the property on the North and East. The records do not show when or by whom this plan or survey was made, nor do they show that any definite arrangement was made to increase the school property from 160 acres to 320 acres.

Indian Agent MacLeod, who has been corresponding in connection with the present site, has suggested that the lands at present under cultivation be surveyed and states that this survey may contain more or less than the original 160 acres, but that he has discussed the situation with the principal men of the Kamloops band, who said they would be satisfied to have the question settled in this way. He also states that he does not consider that the school management could have any serious objection to this solution, as the lands outside the cultivated lands are steep rough hillsides.

I would recommend that a survey be made in order to definitely establish the limits of this school property. If you approve, may I be advised of the name of the surveyor to whom instructions could be issued to perform the survey? This reserve is situated in the Cariboo Electoral District, close to the City of Kamloops. The survey could be most economically performed by a surveyor from that city.

Chief Surveyor.

Sir,

The Department requires a survey of the boundaries of the lands occupied by the Kamloops Indian residential school on the Kamloops Indian reserve. The survey of the parcel is to include all the land at present under cultivation by the school authorities but it is not considered desirable that the boundaries should be jogged in order to follow the limits of the actual cultivation but the parcel should be laid out in as regular a shape as possible to include this area.

I am enclosing a blueprint of the survey of the Canadian Northern Pacific Railway right of way through this portion of the reserve and your field notes should show a connecting tie to either that corner of the reserve marked "P" on this blueprint, or to a monument at one of the lower corners on the other side of the South Thompson river, or if the Company have special hubs marking either the P.C.'s or the P.T.'s of their line, a tie to two consecutive hubs on the railway would be satisfactory.

If you are able to undertake this survey, kindly communicate with Mr. Ewen MacLeod, Indian Agent, Kamloops, who will be in a position to give you definite information as to the location of the boundaries.

The corners are to be marked with posts of the type shown on the enclosed blueprint which you can readily secure from a local blacksmith. Intermediate posts should also be planted every twenty chains.

You will be paid at the rate of $15.00 per day and all reasonable expenses. Your returns will consist of field notes and your account in duplicate, accompanied by duplicate vouchers for expenditures made. If you are unable to accept this survey kindly notify the Department at once, in order that instructions may be issued to another surveyor.

Ottawa, May 2, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

The Department is making special efforts to improve the instruction in manual and vocational training for boys in the Indian schools of British Columbia. If this phase of our educational programme can be made more effective, it will greatly benefit the Indians of the Province. Most residential schools have a workshop or other space that can be used for vocational training. If steps to improve the workshop facilities should be taken at the Kamloops Indian Residential School, please cooperate with Mr. Indian Agent MacLeod with a view to making a recommendation to the Department.

A thorough course in carpentry is the present aim. To this end, Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn has been authorized to supply benches and tools and there has been directed to you a text on manual training, job sheets in woodworking and a publication on how to work with tools and wood. Further, you have been authorized to present reasonable accounts for materials with which to work to Mr. MacLeod.

The Department is desirous of having a qualified instructor for this work at all schools where this special training is being undertaken. Some schools have on the staff an officer who is well qualified for the activity and who can be released from other duties for the manual training classes. I understand there are summer courses for instructors in manual training in Vancouver and Victoria. Other Indian schools are so situated that they can secure the services of instructors from municipal schools. In this case, classes are held two or three times per week. The Department would like to know what arrangements you have made, or can make, for this important work. Do not hesitate to enlist the cooperation of Mr. MacLeod if the Department can be of any assistance.

At a later date, it is hoped to extend the vocational training to include gas engines and other machinery; and, whenever you believe this additional course should be given at the Kamloops Indian Residential School, you will please inform the Department. A copy of this letter is being directed to Mr. MacLeod for his information.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Please find herewith copy of letter received this date from Rev. Father Duplanil, O.M.I., Principal of Kamloops Indian Residential School, with reference to vocational training class at the school.

I might state that on several occasions I have personally visited this class, and find that the boys are doing very good work. They have a careful and painstaking instructor in Mr. Osborne, who submits a weekly report to the Reverend Principal of the School.

Of course the Department is aware that the class is a new one, and it will take some time to teach the children the various works. The reason they are able to construct a large implement and farm machinery shed which they are putting up, is because they are taking down some of the buildings in the vicinity of the old school. All this work will be useful to them when they have left the school.

So far, the call on the Department for lumber material has been light owing to the fact that a great deal of use has been made of the lumber for the old school buildings. However, as noted in the Principal's letter, it will be necessary to get some more lumber in the near future in order to keep the class going. I would like to have a schedule of the work of this nature carried on in other schools, so that we would be guided thereby in laying out and planning work ahead for the children.

In my opinion, while book learning is essential for the advancement of the Indian children, the manual training is equally, or probably more important to them in after life.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Manual training school,
Kamloops Indian School

This class was started Sept. the 21st 1929 with 20 children, ten in the morning class and ten in the afternoon class, each Saturday. In the very beginning they made their benches, complete, they made also the necessary numbers of saw-horses. In fact they equipped the school quite thoroughly and at present it looks very much like a shop well kept and equipped.

The children, then, made waste paper baskets for the class rooms and staff rooms, the morning class making octagonal baskets and the afternoon class, square baskets. Each basket was well made.

At present they are making sixty small tables for the girls' dormitories, to hold wash basin, tooth brush, tooth paste, slippers, etc. Each table is properly doweled and glued together. Each one is hand-planed very smoothly.

Each and all the boys in the Manual training school know the name of the tools used. All the boys know how to sharpen the tools which they used. In this regard they are very good.

It gives me much pleasure to report well on the class work. They have done remarkable progress in such a short time.

Report for 1st quarter.

Quarterly Report on the work done in Manual School.

During the last quarter the pupils attending the Manual training school, have made forty-six cupboards (16 inc. x 5 ft) complete with doors and hooks. They made also three desks for the kindergarten class room with the necessary benches. Several other benches were made also by the boys and these are used in the sewing room for the little ones and in different rooms in the building.

Half of the pupils attending the classes are new ones, having come to the manual training school only in the beginning of the term. They have learned the names of their tools. They have learned how to sharpen them and how to take care of them.

Last year's pupils are quicker to understand the work. Their progress is very satisfactory indeed as it shows that they not only have learned how to work, but they have retained the lessons given them.

The building is too small. We have eleven or twelve boys in each class and there is not enough room for them all. There are not enough benches, the room being already crowded, it is impossible to put more benches.

At the last Fall Fair, the work of the children, exhibited to the Public, not only won general praises from the public, but won the First Prize. Yet the objects exhibited did not represent the best work done by the children, and there were only a few articles on the stand.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) Robert Osborne.

EXTRACT from Inspector Barry's Report regarding his inspection of the KAMLOOPS INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL on November 30th and December 1st, 1931.

Original on File 154-0-6.

Vocational Training:

The Boy's Manual Training is under the charge of a part time instructor, Mr. R. Osborne. This teacher is paid at the rate of $40.00 per teaching month by the Department. Mr. Osborne is, I understand, a cabinet maker in Kamloops and comes each Saturday to the school. Twenty-seven boys are taking the course and these are divided into two classes, working for half a day each. The type of work done is the construction of tables, bookcases, lockers, cabinets. There is not much of the scientific model making done; but there has been considerable work accomplished in the construction of buildings, repair work, and the making of small articles for use in the school.

There has been an addition to the Manual Training Shop since my last report. The room is now about 45 feet by 20 feet. There are two double and eight single benches in the Manual Training Shop.

The chicken house mentioned in my last report is now finished. It has been very well constructed.

The Principal informs me that he purchased five sets of tools for the use of the boys. This was some time ago. He now asks for an additional four sets of tools. About $100.00 worth of lumber for manual training purposes is required. I am more inclined to recommend the sanctioning of this last than I am to recommend the supply of more tools. I believe that the school will be able to get along with the tools they have for some time to come.
Ottawa, February 13, 1932.

Sir:

Mr. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for the Province of British Columbia, in a report on his inspection of the Kamloops Indian Residential School, recommends, regarding the manual training classes, that about $100 worth of lumber be supplied. In this connection I have to request that you will consult the Rev. Principal and the Manual Training Instructor as to the materials required, and you may arrange for the purchase, from indicated sources, of a quantity of lumber not exceeding the sum of $100. After the purchase has been made, you should forward an itemized account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost. Please state on the voucher that same is to be paid from B. C. Special Appropriation.

We are not prepared to supply any additional sets of tools for the manual training work. It is considered that the school should be able to get along with the tools they have on hand for some time to come.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. J. Ferguson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamloops, B.C.

Kamloops Indian Residential School Report of Manual Training for the Months of January, February and March of 1933.

This class consists of thirty boys. 50% of them were beginners at the summer term. These boys are being trained the name and use of wood tools and the sharpening of the same and are progressing very well.

The boys who have been in the Class for two terms are able to do real good jobs in carpentry. They do all the work about the buildings which is quite a lot in a School of this size, in repairs alone, which is splendid training for these boys.

New work such as cupboards, tables, benches, sink drain boards, cabinets and many useful articles are made by the boys.

One piece of work made one Saturday by four of the boys for the Chapel deserves special mention as to their craftsmanship.

As their instructor I take pleasure in submitting this report.

Dear Sir:

In answer to your letter of February 28, Your File No. 154-0-11., I am sending the following report with regard to vocational training given at the Kamloops School:

(a) Instruction.

Brother Joseph, Gardener, 59 years of age, 40 years experience.

James Bann, Farm and Dairy Instructor, 55 years old, 44 years of experience.

Frank Bosco, Technical School Instructor and Shoe Maker, 25 years old, 7 years experience as carpenter, followed course in Vancouver Technical School, 5 years teaching Indian children.

Kitchen and Dairy: Sister M. Thomas, S.S.A., 41 years old, 25 years experience in kitchen and dairy work.

Sister M. Rose Alida, Laundry, 32 years old, 4 years experience.

Sister M. Dolores, Mistress of Junior Sewing Class, 45 years of age, 15 years experience as Seamstress.

Sister M. Moise, Mistress of Senior Sewing Class, 53 years old, 25 years experience.

(b) Industries.

GARDENING:
15 pupils, 15 hours per week.

Farm and Dairy:
15 pupils for milking and tending barn, 14 hrs.
27 pupils doing farm work, 18 hours a week.
2 pupils tending chickens, 14 hours a week.
4 pupils tending hogs, 18 hours a week.

TECHNICAL SCHOOL:
24 pupils, 4 hours a week. The following work has been accomplished during the period from April 1, 1933 to March 31, 1934.
Kamloops Indian Residential School,
Kamloops, B.C.

Vocational Training.

TECHNICAL SCHOOL:

The pupils have been taught the proper use and care of all equipment, how to set and file various kinds of saws; they are shown the necessary wood joints and how to make them and also receive some instruction in finishing.

They have made:
- 6 Medicine Cabinets.
- 2 windows installed.
- Corrugated roofing put on slaughter house.
- 2 large presses made and installed.
- 8 rows of coat and hat hangers installed.
- 10 benches.
- 2 small show cases.
- 8 step ladders of different sizes.
- 1 automatic platform for urinator.
- 2 racks for hanging combs.
- 40 panes of glass replaced.
- 3 sets of clothes' hangers.
- 175 coat hangers.
- 6 wall protectors installed in scullery.
- 36 window hooks replaced.
- 6 tables repaired.
- 12 chairs repaired.
- 2 saw horses made for technical school.
- 18 bench hooks made for technical school.
- 3 tables made.
- 3 chairs made.
- 56 children's sleighs made.
- 1 18ft. painting ladder made.
- 2 Wheel Barrows made.
- 3 High stools made.
- 1 Mail box made.
- 3 Class room platforms made.
- 1 Clock shelf made.
- 2 Picture frames made.
- 4 Technical School benches repaired.
- 5 Table drawers made.
- 2 Sets of pigeon holes made for office desk.
- 18 Radiators refastened to wall.
- 14 doors repaired.
- 2 outside doors repaired including poor brick work.

Large shelving made for storage room.

Shoe Repairing:

2 boys, 15 hours a week have repaired 390 pairs of shoes.

KITCHEN and DAIRY:

80 of the larger girls take their turn in the Kitchen and dairy, 15 a month, working 35 hours a week in the Kitchen and 30 hours a week in the Dairy. They are taught how to prepare meals for both staff and children, how to make butter etc.
Kamloops Indian Residential School,
Kamloops, B.C.

Vocational Training.

Laundry:

No. of Pupils employed:
35 in the forenoon, 4 hours weekly.
30 in the afternoon 5 hours weekly.
Besides learning how to tend the machinery in the laundry all take turns in washing by hand and in ironing.

Junior Sewing Class:

32 pupils in the forenoon, 10 hours weekly.
48 pupils in the afternoon, 12½ hours weekly.
These children mend all the socks and stockings and receive primary lessons in plain sewing.

Senior Sewing class:

37 pupils in the forenoon, 10 hours a week.
17 in afternoon, 12½ hours a week.
Besides a certain amount of embroidery, Drawn work, Knitting, Crochet work, Mending of clothes for both staff and children, these pupils have done the following work:

Aprons 41 doz.
Bloomers 12 doz.
Dish Towels 27 doz.
Face Towels 27 doz.
Handkerchiefs 72 doz.
Kitchen dresses 13 only
Middies 46 only
Night Gowns 8 doz.
Pillow Cases 9 doz.
Summer Dresses 11 doz
Underskirts 14 doz.
Winter Dresses 13 doz.
Sheets 8 doz.
Bathing Shorts 12 doz.

(C) Remarks.

All the Instructors report that in general, the children are very much interested in their work. I am not in a position to judge whether or not the children profit later on by the knowledge and experience they get in school but they are certainly well equipped when they leave school to succeed.

Not having been in charge of this work for long, I am not in a very good position to make suggestions with regard to the manner in which the courses could be improved. If some recompense could be given to the children who show special interest and ability in their work, this would be an encouragement to all. If for instance equipment could be given them when they leave school so that they might continue at once to do the work they have learned in School, this, I think, would be great help. A Number of our boys won prizes as members of the Boys' and Girls' Calf club and this has been a great incentive to them ever since. Our boys did better than the white children of the club who should have had the same opportunities.
Kamloops Indian Residential School,
Kamloops, B.C.

Vocational Training.

Re: Circular Letter of March 18, 1931.

I can say that almost all the instructions contained in this circular are being faithfully carried out in this school. The girls receive a good training in all housework. They learn how to make bread and butter. I do not at the present time see any convenient way for the girls to receive much training in gardening. We are asking the Department for more land, in which case our present garden might be left to the girls for this purpose. It is also very difficult here to have the girls milk cows though most of the girls who come from homes where there are cows are already able to do so. All our milch cows are on the R.O.P. test and in this case the milkers must not be changed but as seldom as possible. We have no facilities for teaching boat making and the study of gasoline engines. I do not think there are many boys here who need this training though there may be some.

With regard to all the other directions of this circular, they are being carried out.

Hoping this report is satisfactory, I remain

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Thos. M. Kennedy, O.M.I.
Principal.

Dear Sir:

- Lumber........ $140.35

- Blacksmith equipment..... $134.07

$345.67

It has been the practice each year to assist the school in this respect to the extent of from $100.00 to $200.00, provision being made in my estimates each year. However, last year the school estimate was prepared by the Department and possible provision has been made to take care of this expenditure.

In the past only material and tools were supplied for the woodwork of this training. This year, as you will note, the requisition covers a complete new outfit of blacksmithing equipment; and I would say that this is a step in the right direction. Training of this nature will put a young Indian in the position that when he returns to his Reserve, he will have some knowledge as to how to repair machinery and other equipment, with which he has to carry on his farm work. In fact I am much in favour of this class of education to the Indians. Both courses are of equal importance and I would strongly recommend that the full requisition be allowed the School.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:-

In reply to your letter dated the 12th of April, regarding one Koehring Cement Mixer with 6 H.P. Novo Gas Engine available at the Department of Public Works here.

I beg to inform you that Mr. K. W. Morton, Acting District Engineer, tells me that this machine has not been in use for several years, although it was in perfect condition when it was put into storage.

It is of very large capacity, in fact much greater than those used for ordinary public buildings, and I do not see how it can be of any use to our Department. I certainly would have no use for it in this Agency.

I understand that the Penitentiary are anxious to get it, and there is no doubt that such a machine would be of value to them for use in the large construction problems they undertake.

This machine is considered to be much too large for any construction work on which it would be employed at our schools, and as the costs of moving the machine from one Agency to another would be a considerable item, I do not consider that this Department should take the machine over.

February 9, 1939.

Dear Sir:

We are endeavouring to place display samples of Eastern Indian handicraft, which is available commercially, in the various national parks as a means of assisting in marketing the goods for the Indians concerned.

Mr. B. I. Love, Superintendent of the Elk Island National Park, Lamont, Alberta, has written advising us that he has arranged space in their Golf-Course Club House for a case of the following dimensions: height 7½ ft., width 3½ ft., and depth 1½ ft. The case is to be placed in a room in which the wood-work is painted white. As we have not funds available from which to supply an ordinary showcase, it has occurred to me that we might take advantage of this opportunity to call attention to the skill of the boys in the manual training class of Kamloops Indian Residential School. I think it would be well to have the case made in two sections, and enclose a drawing with the suggested outline, which you might discuss with the manual training instructor. You will see in the specifications that it is necessary to arrange for moveable shelves, as the baskets to be displayed are different heights and sizes.

Please purchase good dressed lumber of a type which will not be too heavy and which will lend itself to a white enamel finish. You may send the account for the materials required for this case on a separate voucher, and it should be sent to Mr. Love, express prepaid, and the express voucher should be included and attached to your own voucher covering the cost of materials, etc.

I shall appreciate your co-operation in this connection, and when the case is finished, it would be well to have a small neat card, suitably lettered, stating that the case was made by the boys in the manual training class of Kamloops Indian Residential School.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Rev. T.M. Kennedy, O.M.I., Supt. Welfare & Training,
Indian Residential School
Kamloops, B.C.

January 7, 1942.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo with reference to manual training instruction at the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

The programme outlined by Mr. Doucet is being used in the Province of Alberta only during the current academic year and as a result the Department is not prepared to forward it to the Kamloops School. May I point out that Indian residential schools in British Columbia have actually had preferred treatment for many years as regards vocational training. This was made possible by the B.C. Special appropriation which has permitted us to provide funds toward the salary of vocational instructors and the purchase of tools and material. The Indian residential schools in other provinces of Canada do not enjoy this advantage. We are carefully studying the progress of the work in the Alberta schools this year and it is quite possible that we will consider placing the programme in other residential schools during the academic year 1942-43.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. F. O'Grady, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Kamloops, B.C.
Dear Sir:

I beg to advise that I am in receipt of a requisition for tools and supplies for the Kamloops Indian Residential School, on which quotations have been secured as follows:

| Woodwards Stores Ltd. | $354.15     | $82.85     | $32.19   |
| McLennan, McFeely & Prior | $346.66     | $73.39     | $31.31   |

I am informed by the Reverend Principal that he understands the Department has set aside sufficient funds for this purpose to cover the expenditure.

It has been found necessary to secure an amended quotation as the original price given by Woodwards Stores Ltd. is on a lathe that has since been sold out. Also, it was found that the lathe quoted on did not include the bench, which is considered a necessity with this tool.

I consider the quotation of Woodwards Stores Ltd. of $354.15 for the machine tools should be considered as it covers Walker-Turner products, which are thought to be superior to the Delta tools quoted on by McLennan, McFeely & Prior at a cost of $346.66. The latter firm have quoted the lowest price on the hand tools and material of equal quality and, if accepted, would make the total cost $458.85.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant with reference to tools and supplies for the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

You may arrange for the purchase of the hand tools and material required for the vocational training class. It is noted that these can be secured at a total cost of $114.70.

Regarding the power tools, I feel that Inspector Barry and yourself should study the list very carefully. It should be kept in mind that in the vocational classes at our residential schools we are endeavouring to give training which will fit the boys for carrying on work when they return to their home reserves. With this in mind, I believe that the use of hand tools should be stressed. It will only be in very rare cases that power tools will be available on any Indian reserve. The list of power tools should, therefore, be very carefully reviewed and if, due to special circumstances, you consider some or all of the power tools requested should be supplied you may arrange for their purchase.

Yours truly,

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 4th instant, file 154-0-11, with reference to the purchase of manual training tools for Kamloops Residential School, I would advise that it was not until after these goods had been supplied by Messrs. Woodward Stores Limited that it was ascertained by them that they could not secure replacement of this stock from the manufacturers under our priority rating of A.10, which they state is only for maintenance of major equipment already in use and that any new major equipment must have the proper rating attached to the order before they can secure such replacement, this rating requiring to be A.3 or higher.

As this question is also likely to arise in connection with supplies for other Residential Schools, it would be appreciated if you would kindly advise me if it is possible to secure the necessary priority in order to enable this firm to replace these articles on their shelves.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Secretary,

Ottawa, November 25, 1942.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

- Re: Manual training tools, Kamloops Res. School -

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 13th instant in which you intimate that Messrs. Woodward Stores, Limited, have not succeeded in securing replacements for the tools supplied by them to the above-noted school.

I must confess that I am personally incapable of following in any intelligent sense the rules and regulations issued from day to day in respect to preferences, priorities, priority ratings and thousands of other regulations that appear to be in force at the present time. However, the officials of the Purchasing Division, to whom your letter was referred, inform me that this firm can replenish their stocks by making application for and filling in Form PD-IX.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 5th instant, regarding material and equipment requested for the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

I have noted particularly the section of your letter which refers to the purchase of power tools. While the Department realizes that the use of such tools saves considerable time, we are also of the opinion that their use would not provide the training which it is most desirable for Indian boys to obtain. When all is said and done few, if any, of them will have power tools available when they return to their home reserve and, if they have got into the custom of using them, they will not be so likely to put forth the extra effort required in the use of hand tools.

A further thought that I feel we should keep definitely in mind is whether we are operating a vocational room for the training of pupils or a repair room for work required around the school. I realize that for the latter use power tools would be very desirable, but I think you will agree with me that our definite purpose in encouraging vocational training is to prepare the Indian pupils for after life. With the above in mind the Department is not prepared, at the present time, to authorize the purchase of power tools for the vocational training building at the Kamloops Indian Residential School. I note from your letter
that the cost of the materials and equipment, other than power tools, would be approximately $360 and authority is granted for an expenditure of that amount. The account, to which your purchase order should be attached, should reach us before the end of March and should read "Pay from B.C. Special."

On reviewing the requisition it is noted that the school authorities are considering the purchase of flake glue and glue pot. I feel that the manual training instructor at this school should carefully consider the advantages of using casein glue.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Kamloops Indian Residential School

Kamloops, B.C.
February 13th 1944.

Mr. H.E. Taylor
Indian Agent
Kamloops, B.C.

Dear Mr. Taylor:

With reference to the requisition, dated December 21st last, for a Drill Press, a built-in Motor Grindstone and a Disk Sander Machine for the Manual Training Division of this School, I would like to point out that this equipment is necessary along with the other power tools given by the Department two years ago. While the technical training of the boys consists chiefly in the proper use of hand tools, the older among them are very anxious to learn the operation of power tools, the knowledge of which will be very useful to them after School. This year, the boys, under the direction of the Manual Trainer, have undertaken the project of making twenty spinning wheels, which will be given to the senior girls graduating in June. The girls have become very proficient in the carding and spinning of wool and it is felt that if they are given spinning wheels to take home with them, they will make good use of them and will benefit by the training they acquired in School. For the construction of the spinning wheels the Drill Press and Sander Machine are necessary. The built-in Motor Grindstone is necessary for the proper care and sharpening of tools which cannot be done thoroughly by hand.

For the above reasons I would be grateful if the Department would give us the tools in question.

Yours very truly,

"F. O'GRADY" O.M.I.
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Your File 154-0-11

I have to refer to your letter of February 7th regarding the application submitted by Reverend Father O'Grady for equipment and power tools for the manual training division of the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

The Principal was advised of the Department's views with respect to the purchase of power tools and I enclose for your information a copy of his letter of February 18th requesting that further consideration be given to this particular matter for the reasons stated.

Although it is true that in the great majority of cases Indians will not for some years have power equipment for use in their homes and workshops, nevertheless, where power is available the tendency to provide themselves with such equipment is quite noticeable and as the use expands in white settlements there will, no doubt, be a proportionate increase in this direction on neighbouring Reserves. Apart from this, however, instruction in the use of power equipment should be helpful to them in seeking employment off their Reserves, especially where such equipment is in use.

The extent to which the instruction in the use of hand tools should be given is, of course, the responsibility of the Principal of the school and manual training instructor who should see to it that emphasis is laid on this particular division of the training. The presence of power equipment in the manual
training division need not to any important extent interfere with the course of instruction desired by the Department, but could be employed in such a way that instruction in its use could be very helpful to the students when they return to their homes.

I am inclined to believe that the instruction in the use of power tools would be of considerable benefit to the Indian student and I should appreciate the Department's further consideration of this application and also the one submitted on behalf of the Sechelt Indian Residential School, reference your letter 167-18-11 of February 18th. Please let me have a reply by air mail at your early convenience.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

C.C.F. to Nominate Here Monday, May 1

A convention to elect a C.C.F. standard-bearer for the Kamloops constituency will be held at the North Thompson Clinton Club, North Thompson, Monday, May 1.

The following officers will take place during the annual C.C.F. dinner scheduled for that same evening:

- President: Mr. J. W. Truitt
- Vice-President: Mr. H. B. Hartney
- Secretary-Treasurer: Mr. W. M. Smith
- Chairman: Mr. W. M. Smith

These figures are the minimum obligations in each case. Finances will be discussed at length and he would not look on this as a successful form until such time as the party has been organized.

Every section of the unit has been represented by Mr. J. W. Truitt, who has been working hard throughout the year, and he has found that local Victory Loan workers are very enthusiastic and interested in the quota.

Liberals at Coast Meeting

Kamloops Liberal Association was represented at the meeting of the Liberal party at Vancouver Tuesday by Keith Maclellan, Mr. E. D. Murray, Mr. R. H. Carson, M.L.A., and Mr. T. J. O'Neil, M.P.

Now in India

Mr. D. E. McPherson, 334 Nicola Street, has just returned from overseas after three and one-half years abroad. Mr. McPherson, of the Provincial Police city detachment, was stationed in India, where he was charged with breaking and entering, and was arrested for the first time. He probably assisted the robbery of the store.

Coming down Victoria Street about noon yesterday afternoon, Const. MacColl saw a man on the sidewalk near the Mallery Drug Store who appeared to be drunk. As he drew near the man, another man came out of the drug store. Const. MacColl tried to arrest the man, but found him to be drunk. He called the police, but his companions were not there.

Greater Emphasis Being Placed at Indian School on Technical Training: Boys Learn Farming, Mechanics; Girls, Home Arts

Many accounts of the many accomplishments of the boys and girls attending the Kamloops Indian Residential School have been received. The school offers technical training classes for the boys and girls who attend the school. The boys are trained in farming, mechanics, and shoe repairing. The girls are trained in home arts, such as sewing, knitting, and cooking.

1000 Indians Visit Children at School Here; Enjoy Concert

From raw wool to finished sweaters, the students at the Kamloops Indian Residential School have been busy during the Easter concert. The Indian girls have been busy shearing sheep, washing them, feeding them, and spinning yarn on spinning wheels, and weaving it into fabric.

Tag Day Saturday for Merchant Seamen

Tag Day will be held Saturday for merchant seamen. The Tag Day Committee will give the general public an opportunity to purchase tickets for the benefit of the merchant marine by purchasing tickets.

Reducing Hazards

The whole subject," said the letter writer, "is a big one, and will need a good deal of thought."

No Criminal Cases For Kamloops Assizes

There are no criminal cases for the Kamloops assizes. The Kamloops assizes will be held on May 6th.

Promotion for Murray Barbour

Murray Barbour, who has been associated with the branch of Mackenzie, White & Dunsmuir, wholesale concern, for many years, has been promoted to sales representative for the company. He will continue to make his home here.

Canada's Indians Nobly Upholding Traditions

OTTAWA — Canada's Indians are nobly upholding the traditions of their race in the war effort. According to preliminary figures compiled by the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, over 1,400 Indians have already enlisted in the armed forces. The number is expected to be increased considerably as more Indians come forward throughout the country. There are approximately 600 Indian enlistments reported so far, according to the department. Some Canadians, Indians say, are serving in the American air force and may be striking down the enemy with bombs dropped from the tomahawk which they forbore to use in battle.

According to the official records of the department, more than 4,000 Indians have served in the Canadian Expeditionary Force during the war. These Indians represented approximately 30 per cent of the Indian male population of military age.

The first recruit of the Indians to the war was appointed in a particularly fine manner. The Indians remembered that their services were entirely voluntary and that they were exempted from the provisions of the military service act.

The Indians, who gave an excellent account of themselves at the Royal Military College, distinguished themselves most highly for their courage, intelligence, efficiency, thoroughness, loyalty, enthusiasm, and impartiality. They were second to none in their work and their civil life and in consequence were most magnificent. As a result of this excellent record, they rendered valuable service as officers and men in the Canadian Expeditionary Force.

Many Indians in Canada's Forces; Brave Fighters

C.P.R. Has Many Projects Ready for Post-War Days

VANCOUVER — Quite confident of his mission, though uncertain in the outcome of the war and in its aftermath, Mr. W. M. Neel, O.B.E., president of the Canadian Pacific Railway, Montreal, has returned from Europe and the British Isles (London). Mr. Neel's mission was to make certain that there would be no prevarication concerning the young people of Canada and the United States. His belief is that rural electrification will play a part in the post-war period, the latter being made possible by the saving of energy in the form of hydroelectric power.

In northern British Columbia and Alberta, he said, they have vast areas of arable land where crops can be grown under more comfortable conditions than they are on the prairies. You have more coal and better transportation facilities than ever before. You have everything to make life abundant and worthwhile and you are able to hold your own in the world.

NOW SHIPPING LAMB TO UNITED KINGDOM

Hon. James O. Chipperfield, minister of Agriculture, announced that the Meat Board is now making shipments of a quantity of lamb to the United Kingdom in response to a recent order from the Ministry of Food. The shipments, which were made last week, included considerable quantities of mutton.

Under the present arrangement, the government is able to dispose of surplus stocks of meat for shipment to the United Kingdom, and the market for Canadian mutton has been strengthened. The demand for Canadian mutton in the United Kingdom is increasing, and the market for Canadian lamb is improving.

Kamloops, B.C., March 1st, 1945.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

With reference to the erection of a sawmill here on the school property for the instruction of the older boys and the cutting of lumber for the homes of ex-school pupils we discussed in your office in January, if you recall, the possibility of the Department assisting us with what funds there are available. The mill is nearing completion but we still require a power unit for its operation. I have obtained prices on different types of equipment and whether an electric or mechanical unit is installed it will cost $1500. We are at present building a root cellar and will need approximately $500 more for materials to complete it. If the sawmill were in operation we could cut lumber to finish the root cellar and the $500 could thus be saved.

Whatever assistance the Department can give us at this date towards the installation of the equipment necessary for the completion of the mill will be greatly appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

F. O'Grady O.M.I.
Principal.
Ottawa, March 14, 1945.

Dear Father O'Grady:

I discussed your letter of the first instant with Mr. Hoey and we are writing to Indian Commissioner MacKay, authorizing an expenditure of $500.00 for a power unit for the sawmill. You should therefore supply Commissioner MacKay with full particulars regarding the equipment you require.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reverend F. O'Grady, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Kamloops, B. C.
Ottawa, March 14, 1945.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

When Father O'Grady was in Ottawa last month he discussed with us the possibility of our assisting him in the erection of a sawmill on the school property, for the instruction of the older boys. We promised to give him what assistance we could, and on receipt of a recent letter from him it was decided to allow an amount of $500.00. I enclose a copy of our letter to Father O'Grady, and when forwarding the account for the expenditure you should attach copy of your purchase order.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

In connection with the Manual Training Extension Project from this School, which will take the form of constructing new houses chiefly for ex-pupils on the Reserves, I would advise that we will be prepared to construct twenty of these houses in the next fiscal year. At present, at the request of Major MacKay the Indian Commissioner for B.C., we are undertaking to build two three room houses on the Douglas Indian Reserve No.8 according to the following specifications, which would be the same for the twenty houses in question:

- Foundations sills 6 x 6 set on cement blocks 8' apart
- Floor joists 2 x 6
- Floor to be double ply shiplap with paper between inside sheathing, shiplap
- Outside shiplap and "V" joint siding with paper between
- Four windows size 24" x 24" sections, 2 lights each
- Four doors, main door being 216" x 618" with a window light
- Three doors 216" x 616"
- Brick chimney set on wall bracket with minimum 22" outside
- Solid sheeted roof with cedar shingles
- Porch roof over main entrance
- Inside and outside trim on doors and windows
- Two coats of white paint with green trim on exterior
- Roof to be shingle stained and oiled.
- Cement steps to main entrance.

The cost of these houses, as for those on the Douglas I. R. No.8, would be $1700.00 per completed unit. We had to allow a certain amount to cover transportation to the above Reserve because of the distance but that would be offset by the recent rise in the price of materials making the cost of construction now in this area approximately the same.

When preparing the estimates for the next fiscal year I would appreciate your including the amount required for the building of these twenty houses as a Manual Training Extension Project from this School.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa, October 6, 1947.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, British Columbia.

It would be appreciated if we could have your comments on Father O'Grady's proposal. As you allocate our Housing Appropriation money for B.C., it is felt that we might benefit from your experience.

As you are aware, it is the policy of the Department that the individual Indian who benefits from the house, should contribute as much as possible to his new home in the way of labour, materials, etc. Our programme in the Maritimes calls for the benefiting Indian to do everything possible to construct his own home.

Bernard F. Neary,

Inspector Davey has gone over the quotation and has marked in red five items, the purchase of which he considers cannot be justified on educational grounds. These items are of a type which would be found only in a very well equipped garage and would require in some cases expert knowledge for their operation.

Although the Kamloops School has a considerable amount of mechanical equipment it is doubtful if the Department would be warranted in supplying this elaborate equipment, even for the amount of maintenance work which is likely to be done at the School.

W.S. Arneil,

Attached are two requisitions for equipment for the Science Laboratory in the new Kamloops School Block, along with the quotation and description as received from Alex Gair, Cabinet Maker.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have had an interview with Rev. Father McGuire when he handed me the enclosed letter and asked me to write you in connection with his request for the purchase of a Holstein bull from the Experimental farm at Agassiz, the bull first mentioned in the letter being the one he desires to get. I am also writing to Hon. Dr. Tolmie suggesting that his Department might either make a gift of the bull or reduce its price to your Department, and enclose for your information a copy of my letter to him.

About a week ago I went over to the Industrial School and was shown over the barn and the crops by Father McGuire, and what I saw there was a revelation. He has I should think, over 80 acres in crop,—alfalfa, oats, barley, corn, potatoes etc. all looking well. At the time I was over he was cutting his second crop of alfalfa, which was about as heavy a crop as I have seen. He tells me he has already filled the barn with the alfalfa and has to stack his oats and barley outside. The corn he intends to cut for ensilage.
and I would think he will easily fill his silo with same. The root crops were looking splendid. There is a little alkali in the soil in places and potatoes do not seem to do well where this shows, but with the irrigation the alkali is being washed out. He certainly has made a wonderful change at the Industrial School.

The barn was clean and well kept, and he had a few head of cattle in same but only three or four. His idea is to increase the number of stock, and he certainly has far more feed on hand than he can use with the present number and unless he gets more stock he will have to sell the greater part of the feed on hand.

I would urge that your Department should comply with Father McGuire's request with regard to this bull. If the Department of Agriculture can see their way to make a concession to your Department with regard to the price, it would probably help.

I understand from Father McGuire that you purpose coming out this way, possibly next month, and hope I shall see you here if you do come.

Yours truly,

FJF/D

Dear Sir:

She is also testing exceedingly well and is doing well at present. She has a maternal sister that gave over 19,000 pounds of milk as a two year old and 842 pounds of butter.

The dam, Lady Lyons Fairfort, is a fine, big, strong, robust cow, as her picture denotes and will easily make over 20,000 pounds of milk this year. The breeding of this calf I consider is of the very best. You will notice that he is line bred in the blood of Sir Canary Heathhilde. This is the old bull that used to be owned by Mr. J. M. The second calf we have for sale was born on February 9th, 1920, and will be old enough for limited service after Christmas. His dam, as a two year old, produced 12,707 pounds of
milk and 492 pounds of butter in 340 days. She has just recently completed a seven day four year old record of 536.4 pounds of milk and 19.25 pounds of butter. She is a fine, big, straight young cow but has not the record behind her that some of our other cows have. The sire of her calf is a son of Lady Lyons Faforit, the cow of which I enclose a photo. He is sired in turn by Inka Sylvia Beets Ponch, the sire of the famous May Echo Sylvia. From this you will see that the sire of this second calf is a half brother to May Echo Sylvia. We are retaining this sire in our herd at present. On account of this calf being somewhat younger than the first mentioned calf and not having quite as strong a pedigree on the dam's side the price on him is $200. cash, crated, f. o. b. Agassiz and registered in the purchaser's name.

I would like to draw your attention to the fact that our herd is on the Accredited list and has not had tuberculosis now for over seven years. I consider this a great factor to take into consideration when purchasing breeding stock. I should like to know at your earliest convenience whether you decide to buy one of these bulls or not so that if not, I shall be able to offer them elsewhere. The breeding is good and the animals are fit to go at the head of most pure bred herds.

Dear Mr. Scott:

On January 5th we lost eight calves into the Thompson River. Our Farm Instructor, Mr. Hutchings, a good stockman, was taking fifty cattle up to his own ranch to winter. With the boys he proceeded about ten miles and feeding the cattle left them overnight. Being range stock they jumped down a ten foot bank in the morning and went to the open water to drink. Twenty-four of them broke through and went under, eight of them being ours; calves fortunately.

A couple of days later, the Bull which you gave us dropped dead as the boys were leading him to water! He was bled and dressed for examination. Upon opening him they found a small piece of steel wire, evidently from the stable iron; it had pierced his stomach and touched his heart. "Carelessness?" I asked the Veterinary. "Not at all; go on and use the broom; it may not happen again in a hundred years."

Both of these were losses, but fortunately we have felt neither of them because we owe nothing on our cattle. In buying we are conservative. Besides, the calves now coming replace the others.

It would prove expensive to buy a Holstein Bull now fit for service. See enclosure. We might try to shift in some way for this season. Would the Department help us to the extent of fifty dollars? We would
buy a calf a few months old, pay the balance ourselves,
and bide our time.

The Department will be pleased to know that
we are satisfied with all our stock; it is well
and improving daily.

With best wishes,

I remain,
Very truly yours,
James McQuire & Co.

Dear Agent:

The enclosed clipping from the Catholic Register has nothing unusual about it; but it does bring to our mind the value set upon milk by children's welfare societies, and the difficulty encountered by honest working men in having milk for their children.

In view of that value, and of that difficulty, and in view of the pains and expense met by the Department in supplying us with a pump and dairy barn, the enclosed figures regarding butter made at the school possess a certain eloquence. I have some vague recollection of a certain disaster a year ago sweeping away beds, clothes, churns, dishes and separator, which explains the low rate of January and February.

There are now coming into the house about four hundred pounds, or forty gallons, or one hundred and sixty quarts of milk daily. This provides about one quart a day for each individual. We consider this supply very satisfactory. I think that if the Department could see the pale little faces coming into school, and like us, a month later see the rounded cheeks and bright eyes of our little wards, they would know how we appreciate this supply of fresh milk; they would feel some satisfaction in realizing that their efforts to supply this abundance have not been in vain.

On his tours of inspection Mr. Cairns has always complimented us on the healthy looks of our children and encouraged us to continue to adhere to milk as an important factor in maintaining health among our pupils. And Colonel Pragnell, the Inspector of Indian Agencies, likewise, has always held that we could make no mistake in giving milk a prominent place in our commissariat. All our Officers, in fact, have a good word for milk.

This letter is late, Agent, owing to my search for more copies of the enclosure.

If you could give this letter and clipping a circuitous route to the Department through the offices of the offices mentioned, and that of our Indian Commissioner, we would be pleased indeed.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) James McGuire, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 13th inst., re the filling and grading on the southwest corner of the Indian School, I beg to report that, in order to make a good approach to the School, and to fill in the front to correspond to that in front of the centre building and the east wing, it will be necessary to haul about 3500 cubic yards of earth.

This could be obtained from the hillside near to where the road to the School leaves the public highway.

KAMLOOPS INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

KAMLOOPS, B.C. April 22, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

For the past five years many of our graduating students have expressed the desire of continuing their studies beyond the eighth grade but due to lack of classroom space we have not been able to accede to their requests except in individual cases. By September of this year we shall have thirty-two students who could follow a high school course. To accommodate these numbers we feel now that it is urgent to have a separate high school building where a complete course of studies could be given equal to what is being given in regular high schools attended by white pupils. The building should be large enough to provide for the needs, not only of the first year pupils but also for those who wish to complete the twelfth grade. It also should be of a style and structure in keeping with the modern main building.

In view of the above it is proposed that a building of approximately the same size and construction as the Cowichan Indian Consolidated Day School at Duncan, B.C., be erected here on the school property. I submitted the plans of this school to an architect requesting that he estimate the cost of constructing a similar building with running water, washrooms and lavatories and radiators in all rooms fed from our main heating system. The total cost, he said, would be $2200.00. There is difficulty, of course in these times, to secure materials but since we have a sawmill the lumber for the forms and framework could be cut here. If it is agreeable to the Department we could supervise the construction of the building in the same manner as the new barn six years ago.

Because of the added expense in conducting a high school and of the larger number of pupils in attendance it would be necessary to allow an increase of thirty in the per capita grant and make provision for the salaries of high school teachers. Although we realize that, in the current year's estimates no provision has been made for these expenses
and the construction of the building still we hope that the Department will be able to find the necessary funds. We should like, if possible, to have the classrooms ready for September.

Because of the need of higher education for our Indian boys and girls it is hoped the Department will favorably consider the high school and proceed to the construction of it at an early date.

Yours sincerely,

"F. O'Grady, O.M.I."
Principal
Dear Mr. Hoey:

You will no doubt recall that during a recent visit Reverend Father O'Grady, Principal of the Kamloops Indian Residential School, made to the Department the matter of extending the work at Kamloops to include high school instruction was discussed. In recent weeks the Principal has on two occasions discussed this matter with me and has followed these discussions up with a letter requesting that action be taken to erect a suitable building for the purpose, the building suggested being along the lines of the St. Catherine's Indian Day School at Duncan. A copy of Reverend Father O'Grady's letter is attached hereto.

I should say that this is a move that has been contemplated for some time and now that the Indians are demanding high schools and receiving firm support from the public in this regard, the matter is one that should receive early attention. However, unless funds could be provided in the current fiscal year for the construction of a suitable building there would be no point in going fully into the matter at this time. On the other hand if it is possible to secure the amount required or a substantial portion of it this year the Principal would be prepared to undertake construction on a straight cost basis along the lines he employed in connection with the school barn, a project that was carried out at very reasonable cost and with much credit to the Principal and the school. Nearly all the ordinary lumber required in the construction could be purchased from the school mill, thus ensuring the supply of materials so difficult to get from local lumber dealers.
I am convinced that accommodation for advanced education should be provided as soon as possible and would appreciate being advised if there is any likelihood of the Department being in a position to undertake construction of a suitable high school building at Kamloops this year.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

For the past several years we felt we should have had a high school for our graduating students most of whom expressed the desire to continue further with their studies. The Indian parents frequently have mentioned to me that they would like their children to go to high school so that they would be able to compete with white boys and girls of their own age who have had the benefits of higher education. In general I would say the desire to proceed with higher studies has, in late years, become widespread throughout this Province. I should like, if possible, to begin the construction of the building at an early date to allow our graduates of this year to commence their high school studies in September.

With kindest personal regards,

Dear Mr. Glen:

For several years we have felt the need of a high school for our graduating students, many of whom have expressed the desire to continue further with their studies. I would say that this need has become more pronounced each year due to the fact that the Indians themselves feel they require higher education in order to take their place among white people today. Their organizations, The Native Brotherhood of B.C. in particular, and other organizations in the Province have been critical of Indian education because no high school facilities at the residential schools are provided for their children. I think the time has come when an effort should be made to provide high school education in this area for the large number of graduates who leave school each year. I discussed the matter in detail with Indian Commissioner MacKay and he is very much in favour of having a high school constructed in connection with this school. It was proposed that a building be erected similar to the Cowichan Indian Day School at Duncan, B.C. It would be large enough to provide for the needs of all the pupils who graduate from this school and also for any who wish to attend as day students from the nearby reserves. It would have classroom space for all the grades up to and including Grade XII. The students could then take a full high school course. I understand Indian Commissioner MacKay will submit the plan in detail for your approval.

I am keenly interested in this high school project. This is the largest Indian Residential School in Canada and I feel
we should show leadership in the development of our educational system for the good of our students and also to prove to the public in general that we are doing all in our power for the advancement of the Indians.

Dear Major MacKay:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, enclosing a communication from the Principal of the Kamloops School, with reference to providing high school facilities at that institution.

This Branch is sympathetically disposed towards Father O'Grady's suggestion, but, as you realize, it is a distinct change in our former policy and, consequently, the matter will have to receive very careful consideration.

If the Principal's recommendation were followed, it would involve keeping both boys and girls to a much older age than at present. As you will realize, this would present certain difficulties. It would not be advisable to keep children of high school age in dormitories with younger children. It appears to me that special living accommodation would be necessary. This would involve additional staff, not only during classroom hours but during their free hours. There are many other phases of the situation that would have to receive very careful consideration before we could proceed along the lines Father O'Grady suggests.

I have always felt that when Indian children wish to take high school work it is preferable to have them attend a white high school, provided of course that we can secure some supervision for them in their free hours. Is there a high school in the city of Kamloops? Has any consideration been given to having children reside at the Kamloops Residential School but attend the white high school? Such procedure has been adopted at several Indian residential schools in Manitoba and Ontario and has been satisfactory.
