DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Leslie Lewis, aged 9 years, 9 months, Pupil No. 412, of the Kamloops Indian Residential School at Kamloops, who died at Royal Inland Hospital, (place) on September 24th, 1935, Kamloops, B.C.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Form No. 414.
A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick? September 22nd., 1935.

2. At what time of day? 4:00 P.M.

3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness? Brother McGourly.

4. What means were taken to afford relief? Called Dr. Tennant who engaged a Registered Nurse to take charge of the case.

5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? 3 gr. Luminal and ice cap ordered by Dr. Tennant.

6. When was the doctor called? 7:00 P.M., September 22nd., 1935.

7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport? 9:00 A.M., September 23rd., 1935., by automobile.

8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school?

9. Add any other useful information here.

Saw patient at 6:00 A.M. September 23rd and did not think there was any immediate danger.

[Signature]
Principal.

NOTE: If the deceased pupil dies in hospital at a distance from the school, under the care of the physician or surgeon who attends him at the hospital, a clinical report of the patient's illness and death in the hospital is to be secured and attached to this memorandum.
B. STATEMENT OF THE PHYSICIAN WHO ATTENDED THE DECEASED PUPIL

I attended Leslie Lewis from September 23rd, 1935 to September 24th, 1935. The immediate cause of death was Status Epilepticus.

The contributory cause of death was Boy was recovering from measles which probably determined the onset of epileptic attack.

Do you consider that the Principal of the School, and the members of the School staff exercised reasonable care and judgment in regard to the illness and death of this pupil? Yes.

Did they follow out your professional instructions? Yes.

If in either respect, you consider them to have been at fault, it is required that you express your carefully considered views as follows:

The boy was given all possible attention while ill in the school.

Autopsy performed and autopsy report submitted by Dr. A.G. Naismith.

P.S. Tennant M.D.
C. STATEMENT OF INDIAN AGENT

1. Having heard and read over the statements of the Principal and the Physician, do you consider that all essential circumstances relating to the death of Leslie Lewis have been recorded? Yes. If not, you are required to add here any further particulars which strike you as essential.

Remarks: The Father, Joe Lewis, in the presence of Dr. Tennant and myself gave his consent to the autopsy being performed. The parents were not present at the enquiry.

2. In this space record any recommendations which the Board consider should be made to the Department in relation to the health or safety of the pupils of this School.

As an epidemic of measles was indirectly responsible for this death, it might be well to point out that the sleeping accommodation for 285 pupils in the school consists of five dormitories, which are crowded. During an epidemic it is impossible to properly isolate the patients and contacts. The need for separate quarters to house sick children is evident.

Chairman—Indian Agent.
Copy of notes on Autopsy. Body of Indian boy Leslie Lewis. Service of Dr. Tennant who was present and identified body.

Partial Autopsy. Head only.

On opening the head, slight congestion with marked increase in cerebellar fluid was noticed.

The base of the brain showed accumulations of serous fluid under the pia mater.

The brain tissue was markedly oedematous. No evidence of tubercles or any septic condition found.

Further tissue study was not carried out.

These findings are in keeping with the clinical diagnosis of status epilepticus.

A.G. Macmillan

REPORT ON DEATH OF JOSEPHINE LOUIE

The child was brought by truck to Kamloops Indian Residential School from Kelowna on Saturday, the 1st of September.

On arrival the child made no complaints but wanted to lie down. On Sunday, September 2nd, she complained of headache and vomited. This was attributed by the school staff to over-eating the day before. During Sunday night, the child vomited several times and headache increased. Vomitus was green and mixed with mucus.

The doctor was notified at 8:30 a.m. on Monday morning, September 3rd, and the child was seen at 9:00 a.m. and sent into hospital, at 9:30 a.m. The child's condition suggested a toxemia. She was complaining of severe headache and pain in the abdomen. She answered questions but was irrational in her replies at times.

No opisthotonos was present. Tendon reflexes were increased. No Kernig present. Abdomen was flat with generalized tenderness, but no area of acute local tenderness. No pathological signs present in lung examination except an air hunger suggesting a diabetic coma. On sending to hospital, the urine was examined for sugar but only showed a faint positive reaction. The pulse was slow, breathing rapid with apparent air hunger. Temperature 100 degrees F. 101 degrees Fahrenheit. The child died 24 hours after admission to hospital. The main cause of death appeared to be gastro enteritis and cerebral toxemia, probably from poisoning from ingested food.

A family history indicates that other children in the family at home in the Penticton area were suffering from similar symptoms. Enquiries are being made re their condition and food supplies through Dr. George Payne at Penticton.

On the morning of September 3rd, the patient was seen by Dr. H.B. Burris of Kamloops. Cause of death was given as food poisoning.

F.S. Tennant, M.D.

Mr. Sloan, M.P., forwards a letter from the Rev. Dr. Whittington with regard to a petition which was sent to the Department some time ago for a grant to the Indian Girls' Home at Kitamaat.

The Department provides for the salary of a day school teacher at this place, and in Mr. Inspector Green's report on the day school there is no mention of boarders being kept there. The school is in charge of Miss Dorothea Bower, M.D.

Sir:

I have the honor to submit the following report of my inspection of the Kitamaat Boarding School (Methodist) North West Coast Agency; inspected on April 1st and 2nd, 1909.

STAFF:
Miss Jackson, Principal and Matron, Salary $450 Per annum.
Miss Mary E. Lawson, Teacher, " $400 "
Miss Donaugh, Sewing Teacher, " $400 "

ENROLLMENT:
Twenty-one pupils, eighteen girls and three boys were enrolled all being present at inspection.

WHERE RECRUITED:
All of the children were from Kitamaat Village.

RESULT OF EXAMINATIONS:
The pupils did very well in reading, spelling, writing, history, arithmetic, geography and grammar. Their songs and physical exercises were also very good.

GENERAL CONDITION OF SCHOOL WORK:
The general condition of school work is good. The pupils, with the exception of two girls who by turns assist in the cooking, attend two sessions a day, and have an hour's preparation in the evening.

EQUIPMENT OF CLASS ROOMS:
They have all necessary material for carrying on successful work.

GARDENING:
Half an acre is cultivated in which small vegetables are grown.

LIVE STOCK:
There is one cow, and a good stable for its accommodation.
DAIRY:

One cow is milked but no butter is made as the milk is used by the pupils and staff.

INDUSTRIES:

The girls are taught bread-making, cooking, general house-work, sewing, laundry work and fancy work.

The boys cut up and carry in the wood.

SANITARY CONDITIONS:

The children all appear to be in good health.

FOOD:

The food is good, well prepared and sufficient.

CLOTHING:

The children were all dressed neatly and suitably for the winter. At the time of my visit there were four feet of snow on the ground.

DRAINAGE:

The drainage is very good.

VENTILATION:

The ventilation is good, better than at any other school in the Province. There are pipes to carry off the foul air and others to let in the fresh air in every room.

FIRE PROTECTION:

Pipes with taps and hose are laid on each floor. On the third floor there is a balcony with a door leading from the halls, with ladders outside to the ground. There are two outside entrances on the main floor, and a door and windows in the basement. Fire-hose on a reel is attached to an hydrant just outside of the building.

The pressure is sufficient to throw a stream over the roof of the building.

RECREATION & EXERCISE:

Calisthenics are taught and the pupils play ball and engage in all kinds of games.

DISCIPLINE & PUNISHMENTS:

The discipline is good and there is no need for any severe punishment.
REWARDS:

Prizes are given for good conduct, for proficiency in classwork and for work cheerfully and well done.

BUILDINGS:

The building is an entirely new one, built by the Woman's Missionary Society of the Methodist Church to replace the one burned on May 20th, 1906. It is a frame building with all modern conveniences, hot and cold water, is heated by furnace, and has two cooking, and one Laundry range. The institution has been furnished throughout by the same Society, and the children's dormitories are furnished with iron beds and cots, mattresses, and good warm bedding. The toilets, lavatories, and bathrooms are equipped with the latest improved methods.

The cost of the building was about $12,000.00. The size of the building 40' x 70', three stories, basement, ground floor, and second floor, with accommodation for thirty-five pupils, twenty-five girls and ten small boys.

The institution was opened on December 10th, 1908. I went carefully over the building and found it very complete. An air-shaft up through the centre of the building makes the ventilation perfect in every room.

I would respectfully recommend that this school be given a Boarding School Grant for thirty pupils.

The Staff is a good one and they expect to add another member when they take in more pupils.

As the Indians of Kitamaat are so often away from their Village the boarding School was much needed.

Everything was neat and in good order in this new school.

I have the honor to remain

Your obedient servant

Inspector.

Sir,

I have the honor to forward my report on the application made to have the Kitamaat Boarding School graded in Class "A" instead of Class "C" as at present, in accordance with Departmental letter No. 389760/1, dated February 26th., 1913.

I visited this school on the 8th. and 9th. of April, and very carefully inspected the school, and find in regard to the "eight clauses" mentioned in your letter which set forth the requirements for schools in Class "A" are as follows:

1. They have a substantial wood building erected in 1908 at a cost of $12,000.00, size 40x70, three stories with basement under the whole building. All is in good repair.

2. The foundation on posts or piles. Two thicknesses of boards have been placed as a lining inside these posts since last inspection, so that the basement is now tight and warm. These foundation posts or piles are inclined to sink but the Principal informs me that the Woman's Missionary Society is ready to put in a cement foundation immediately.

3. There is a plentiful supply of water, water taps on each floor. This has been changed and greatly improved since my last report. Pipes are underground, well covered so safe from frost.

4. Sanitary closets and drains are up-to-date. Sewage is carried to tide water. Baths are in perfect order and constantly flushed.

5. There is an isolation ward meeting all requirements for a hospital. This can be cut off from the other part of the house and has a verandah or sleeping porch attached thereto.

6. Ventilation in connection with the cold air shaft is very good, indeed it is one of the best ventilated schools on the coast. There is accommodation for thirty-four pupils. The dormitories

Sir,

I have the honor to report that during the early part of May there was serious disturbance in the Boarding School at Kitimat. Miss Ida M. Clarke, the principal was at the time in Vancouver for a month's holiday; and the school was in charge of one of the teachers, Miss Hortop.

The immediate cause of the trouble was that a pupil, Hannah Maclean, adopted daughter of Wm. Grant, became ill, and the parents alleging ill-treatment took the girl to their own home in the village: here she died two days afterward, namely on May the 8th.

The whole village became greatly excited; and, when the pupils were allowed to go for a visit to their homes, as has been the custom every Saturday afternoon, the children did not return to the school.

Notice of this was sent to the principal in Vancouver, and to this office, said information arriving here May 28th. Miss Clarke at the same time came to Bella Coola from Vancouver; and we left for Kitimat on the 31st, calling at Ocean Falls for

Secretary, Dep't of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Corpl. Clearwater, R.C.M.P.

We arrived at Kitimat June 4th, and found only five pupils in the Boarding School.

The next day a meeting was held with the natives, at which also were present: Miss Ida Clarke, the principal, Miss S.E. Alton, field matron, Rev. E. Coulgray, missionary, constables Clearwater and Sutherland, besides the Indian agent.

Several Indians spoke and complained that the school was injurious to the health of the pupils, that there was not proper medical service, and that the children were not properly fed or clothed. One made the statement that of all the girls who had attended the school 49 have died, and 50 are alive.

Miss Clarke, the principal, and Miss Alton, the field matron replied to the charges of the Indians. Corpl. Clearwater, and the Indian agent also spoke to the meeting of the rights of the Indians to make complaints, if they had cause for it; but they should not take the matter in their own hands: that both the Indians and the school had rights that must be respected. On behalf of the Department I promised the natives that a physician would visit the school after the fishing season, and examine the children, and sanitary conditions in the school.

The Indians at last agreed to return the children to the school, if the principal would sign a paper that the children would be properly fed.

Miss Clarke signed a paper to this effect; and, on behalf of the Indians two of them signed a statement that they would give the school proper support. Corpl. Clearwater and the Indian agent examined into the death of Hannah Maitland. Sworn statements were made by Miss Alton, field matron, and Miss Hortop, teacher. It was the opinion of
Miss Alton that the child had died of spinal meningitis. It would appear from the evidence that they had given the child care and attention to the best of their knowledge, and ability. No physician is nearer than Prince Rupert, 125 miles away, by water.

We went through the whole school from the basement to the attic, and also inquired into the question of food given the children. The principal explained that it was often impossible to obtain fresh meat or fish; but the children always had sufficient food to eat, and three meals were served every day.

Before leaving the school we addressed the children, and asked them if they had any complaints to offer, as to food or treatment. As could be expected they remained silent. Indian children, in such circumstances, from diffidence, seldom or never speak, when questioned by white people.

The school, upon inspection, appears cleanly and sanitary, and the children appear well clothed and fed.

An Indian, John Adams was convicted of having used insulting language to Miss Hortop, and sentenced to pay a fine of $20.00 with the option of two months in jail; he paid the fine.

The Indians seemed to have taken a strong dislike to one of the teachers. Such feeling, however unreasonable or unmerited, is hard to remove from an Indian's mind. It is understood that at the end of the present year, this teacher's term of service will end, and she will then leave the school.
This report of a matter, delicate to handle, and difficult to set right, is most respectfully submitted, one copy being forwarded to Mr. R.C. Cairns, Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, June 27, 1922.

Sir:-

I have to acknowledge receipt of yours of the 15th instant, reporting the serious disturbance which occurred at the Kitamaat Indian Boarding School in the early part of May, last. It is noted that the immediate cause of the trouble was the serious illness and death of one of the pupils, and that the Indian parents considered that proper medical treatment had not been applied.

The action taken to explain matters to the Indians is approved.

It is noted that the teacher, to whom the Indians have taken such a strong dislike, will terminate her services at the end of the present year. It is presumed that this means the end of the present school year, viz., June 30th.

We notice that upon inspection the school was found to be cleanly and sanitary and that the children were well clothed and fed. It is hoped that the dissatisfaction of the Indian parents will gradually die out and that, when the change in teachers is made, there will be no further cause for any complaints regarding the management of this school.

You should arrange for the visit of a physician to this school at an early date, and he should examine all the children and give instructions to the staff regarding any treatment required. He should also inquire thoroughly into the sanitary conditions and the nutritious value of the food supplied to ascertain whether any change in diet should be made.

I shall be pleased, at a later date, to receive the report of the doctor after his visit and inspection of the pupils and the school, generally.

Your obedient servant,

Re: KITIMAT INDIAN RESERVE:
Re: Hanna GRANT Deceased.

The sworn statement of Miss Mary HORTON, Occupation: Domestic Science Teacher; Residence: Elizabeth Long Memorial Home, on the Kitimat Indian Reserve, at Kitimat, B.C.

Hanna Grant, age approximately 8 years, became ill while an inmate of the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home, April 29th, 1922. She told me that she had a headache, so I told her that she had better remain in bed, so she stayed in bed all day Friday the 29th of April 1922, and the only time she got out of bed after this was on Saturday morning April 30th from about ten A.M. until about 1:00 P.M. She appeared to be too ill to sit up, as she was lying on a sofa most of the time, so at last I requested her to go back to bed, which she did. There was no Doctor available, but Miss Alton, Field Matron (Nurse) gave her medical attention from the time she became ill until Saturday May 5th at which time she was removed from the home by her parents.

Miss Alton's directions were carefully followed, and we (meaning the Ladies in charge of and residing at the 'Home') did all that was possible to save the child's life, and from the time her illness became serious someone was in attendance day and night.

For the first two or three days she lay very quiet and complained of a headache most of the time, after that she could not seem to keep anything on her stomach. She vomited several times during the last few days she remained in the Home. She appeared to suffer from a severe attack of "La Grippe". The parents came for the child about ten O'clock May 6th (A.M.), and we could not very well prevent them from taking her. They took her to their home in the village of Kitimat, where she died on the 8th day of May 1922.

The parents made no complaint at the time regarding the treatment which their child had received while an inmate of the 'Home', but thought that they should have been notified regarding her illness sooner. We thought that they knew about the child being ill. I believe that the removal of the child from the 'Home' at least hastened her death.

Signed ....... Mary HORTON.

SWORN BEFORE me, this 4th day of June 1922, at Kitimat, B.C.

(Sgd.) Iver Fougner,
Indian Agent for the Bella Coola Indian Agency.

Re: Hanna GRANT; Deceased.

The sworn statement of Miss Sarah Elizabeth Alton;
Occupation: Field Matron; Residence: Kitimat Indian Reserve, Kitimat, B.C.

I went up to the home (Elizabeth Long Memorial Home) Friday afternoon April 29th, 1922, and I was informed by Miss Hortop that an Indian girl, inmate of the home, named Hanna Grant had become somewhat ill that day, and upon investigating I found that this girl had a temperature of 100 degrees, but otherwise she did not appear to be seriously ill.

I prescribed the usual medicines given a patient for "La Grippe" and also mustard applications to be applied twice daily. I visited this patient twice, and sometimes three times daily, until she was removed from the home by her parents on the 6th day of May 1922. I was unable to visit her home in the village owing to the fact that I was suffering from an injured ankle at the time. Had she have been left at the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home I would have continued my medical attention. However, Rev. Gouldrey, who has had medical experience, visited her at her home and did all he could.

It was reported to me early Monday morning May 6th, 1922, that Hanna Grant had died about 6:00 A.M. There is no doubt that this girl would have received better treatment had she have remained in the Home, however her mother would not consent to have her remain there. I understand that the Mother permitted this patient to have any food she desired, including many solid foods which should not have been given to her while she had such a high fever. Her fever varied from 100 degrees to 102 degrees. There was certainly no neglect on the part of the Officials at the home regarding the care of Hanna Grant while she remained an inmate of that institution.

(Sgd.) Sarah Elizabeth ALTON.

Sworn before me

an Indian Agent;

Sir:

I have the honour to report that acting upon information received I proceeded to Kitimat, B.C., accompanied by Indian Agent Iver Fougner, arriving there on Saturday June 3rd, 1922.

We found that all Indian children had been withdrawn from the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home, a boarding school situated on the Kitimat Indian Reserve, by their parents as the result of the death of Hanna Grant, who died on May 8th 1922. We also found that a petition had been drawn up by the natives of the village, and signed by practically every one of them old enough to sign, demanding the dismissal of all teachers of the aforementioned boarding school, it being alleged in this petition that the Indian children inmates of the Home had been compelled to eat rotten fish and eat meal with worms in it. I did not take a copy of this petition, but I understand that Indian Agent Iver Fougner is forwarding the same to the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa.

On Monday June 5th, 1922, a meeting was held by the Indians in their Hall on the Kitimat Reserve at which the Indians invited Mr. Fougner and I to preside, table and chairs being arranged accordingly. Mr. Fougner, acting as chairman of the meeting took down (in writing) the minutes of the meeting in detail. I, acting as Mr. Fougner's assistant, entered notes of all important statements in my note-book; I beg to quote a summary of the same hereunder.

Meeting called to order by Indian Agent Iver Fougner at 10:45 A.M. Edward Grey, Indian, states: "Last year I saw my child getting pale. I asked those at the Home if they had examined them (apparently he had two children in the Home at this time). They said no. I spoke them again. Later she died in the night. Then another child of mine, an older daughter became ill at the Home. She was pale and thin. I took her away and believe I saved her life by doing so. When Hanna Grant died this year, it was considered by the Indians that her death came as the result of neglect at the Home. Another reason which caused dissatisfaction among the Indians was the fact that Hanna Grant's Parents were not notified sooner."

Miss Alton, Field Matron, then stated that the parents were notified on Wednesday prior to the child's death on the following Monday.

At this stage of the meeting a letter was handed to the Indian Agent from the parents of Hanna Grant in which it was alleged that the child died as the result of chloroform administered by Miss Alton in order to put her to sleep. Miss Alton: "I have no chloroform in my possession, I never use it."
Edward Grey, continuing stated that the Ladies at the Home complained about Hanna Grant screaming during the night thereby disturbing their sleep during the last few nights she remained there, and that the said Ladies administered a Narcotic or sleeping draught in order to keep her quiet. He said the Indians called it chloroform because they knew no better. He would not say it was chloroform, but it was some drug which had a similar effect.

Mr. Willie Grant, father of the deceased child, stated that his daughter informed him the day he removed her from the School (Home) that she had not been receiving sufficient food. He also stated that he called at the Home one night about 11:00 O'clock and Miss Hortop told him that Miss Alton had given the child a powder to make her sleep, as she was getting tired of looking after her. She had not recovered from the effects of drugs when he removed her from the Home.

Miss Alton: "I believe the child died of Spinal Meningitis with complications, and with that disease the patient usually goes into a coma or stupor during the last few days of their life."

Herbert McMillan, Indian, stated that Miss Alton admitted to Mrs. Grant, the child's Mother, that she gave Hanna sleeping powders. In reply Miss Alton stated that she gave the child a powder to ease her pain, not to make her sleep.

Jacob Duncan, Indian, stated that after the death of Hanna Grant the parents of those children remaining at the Home held a meeting and talked about the girls that had attended the Home. Since the Home started forty nine had died, and fifty were still alive, and the Indians did not understand why these deaths occurred. They did not know what caused the deaths. Duncan then went on to say that at the conclusion of their meeting those present wrote a word to the Council, who took the matter up and called some of the children from the home, and asked them how they were fed. The children stated that they were forced to eat rotten fish and rat meal with worms in it. Gertrude Grant, and all the big girls told this story. The Council decided that they themselves could not close the Home, so they called a meeting of all the people in the village, and all the parents of the children agreed to have their children removed from the Home, and keep them at their own homes, because of the ill treatment at the Home, in the way of not getting sufficient clothing and food, and they agreed to keep their children at their own homes until all Ladies, (Teachers, etc.) at the Home are discharged, and new appointments made.

Mr. Fouquer then made a brief speech, informing the Indians that he did not think they could get better teachers, and that there were several other Indian Reserves in his Agency where such a school would be appreciated. Interruption by the Indians: "They are welcome to it!" followed by great applause on the part of the Indians.

Herbert McMillan, Indian, then stated that the Indians did not wish to close the school, if the children were treated right. We only want people to treat our children right. We want our children educated, and we are always willing to help."
Timothy Starr, Indian, stated that he was a pupil in a Boarding School at ? (near Port Simpson, I believe) and was far better treated there. No one ever went short of food.

David Grant, Indian, stated that the children required a better education. The boarding school at Kitimat had been the same for the past twenty years. The children were learning nothing.

Mr. Fougner then informed the Indians that they had no authority whatever to withdraw their children from the home, after having signed a contract for them to remain there.

In reply the Indians claimed that the contract with the school was to the effect that the children would be well cared for, provided with sufficient clothing, food, etc. One of the Indians stated he had supplied all the clothing for his child. He asked Miss Clarke, head teacher who was present, if this was true. She replied that it might be so if the Indians wished to supply clothing for their children the school did not duplicate, but that they were not compelled to supply clothing.

The Indians still seemed to be in a very hostile mood, so I decided to address them. My speech took up about half an hour's time. I outlined the situation, as best I knew how, explaining that we were not out to persecute the Indians, that I desired to see them get a fair deal at all times, but that they must abide by the law of the country the same as white people had to. They were certainly not authorized to take the law in their own hands, as they had done in this case, and furthermore if the matter went any farther it would have to be brought up in Court, which I felt sure was not desired by anyone present, besides the matter had to go to Court, then practically all that they had told Mr. Fougner would be useless as most of it was hearsay. I emphasized the fact that if they went to Court they must state facts and nothing else. I informed them that they might be given up to six months with Hard Labour for the unlawful acts which they had committed, however, I sincerely hoped that there would be no necessity for imprisonment, especially at this time of the year when they had such great opportunities to make big money logging and fishing. I mentioned that there was no country in the world where Indians were treated better than they were under the British Flag. I also called their attention to the fact that the Canadian Government had become very poor owing to the Great War, in which white people fought and gave their lives, while the Indians were allowed to live in peace, enjoying the privileges and protection of the British Flag. The Canadian Government had spent a large sum of money during the last few years endeavouring to educate the Indians, and help them to lead better lives in every way, but that there was a limit to what the Government could do for them. The Government could not give them something new in the way of schools etc., every day.
I pointed out that there was nothing wrong about them making a complaint if they did so in the proper manner, in writing through their Indian Agent to the Department of Indian Affairs, but by taking the law in their own hands they had committed a serious offence, and they could consider themselves lucky that they were not all in gaol.

Referring then to the subject of food, I asked Miss Clark if she was willing to admit the parents of the children to the Home at meal times so that they might see for themselves just what their children were eating. She stated that she had no objections. I then questioned her regarding the amount of clothing allowed her, as to whether she was allowed sufficient to clothe the children properly. One of the principal complaints of the Indians had been in connection with the shoes supplied to the children at the Home. Miss Clark admitted that the shoes she had received during the past year were not the best, and that there had been a shortage of them, but stated that she had bought new rubbers for every girl in the school in order that they might keep their feet dry.

Then after advising the Indians that they had nothing to gain by keeping their children out of school, I asked for a vote to be taken among themselves as to what they intended to do. They agreed to send the children back to school provided that Miss Clark would sign her name to a paper before us that she would see that the children got all the food they wanted, that they would be well cared for, and be supplied with sufficient clothing. Miss Clark agreed to sign and did sign the required paper. I then gave instructions to the Indians that every child was to be returned to the school that day.

The meeting closed at two P.M.

Returning from Kitlohe on the 7th day of June 1922, I again called at Kitimat and found that all children in the village except that of Edward Grey had been returned to the Home. He had just arrived in from camp, and sent his child to the Home as he arrived there on the understanding that he was to be allowed to take her with him to see Doctor Bailey at Rivers Inlet when he goes fishing at that place. Miss Alton agreed to let the child go when the time comes as the glands in her throat should be removed. Miss Alton informed me that the other child which Grey complained about dying in the Home had the same complaint, (swollen glands) she did all she could for the child, which Grey admitted. He agreed to leave his child at the Home until his departure for Rivers Inlet. I might mention here that Grey is a very well educated Indian, and that he has some knowledge of Law.

I attach hereto the Sworn Statements of Miss Hortop and Miss Alton regarding the death of Hanna Grant.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
your obedient servant,

Sir:

Further to my report of last P.M.13th inst., I have the honour to report that I, accompanied by Indian Agent Iver Fouger, inspected all food and quarters at the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home, Kitimat, June 4th, 1922. At that time the quarters were clean and in good order.

I took special care to examine the fish and oat meal on hand at the Home on the above mentioned date. There were three barrels of fish in brine, in the basement. The fish looked clean and suitable for table use. I would mention here that Miss Clark (who had been absent when the trouble occurred, returning to Kitimat with us) explained how some tainted fish might have been placed on the table. She stated that just before leaving, some fresh fish were brought to the Home, which she ordered placed in some old brine, expecting that these fish would be used in a few days. She stated that the brine in question was quite good enough to have kept the fish for a few days, but not for any great length of time. She had expected that these fish would be used as quickly as possible. Apparently the fish referred to were left in the brine for several days, and it is quite possible that they became somewhat tainted. However, Miss Clark went on to say that the children were certainly not compelled to eat them. It appears that the Indian girls do their own cooking, and consequently they should not have cooked any bad fish, as there was plenty of others in good condition.
Regarding the oat meal Miss Clark stated that she never saw any worms in it. I noticed that this oat meal was in a large wooden bin, in the kitchen cabinet, and from enquiries made among several cooks since that date, aboard boats and elsewhere, I have obtained the information that it is not unusual to find a worm in such cereal. However, I do not believe that the Indian Children at the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home would be asked to eat any article of food in which a worm had been found.

I mentioned to Miss Clark that should a worm be found in any article of food supplied to the Indian Children that particular article should be thrown away. The children should not be asked to eat it, even though the worm had been removed.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
your obedient servant,

Referring to your letter of 14th instant, I have the honor to report as follows:

Some years ago our Department established a water system at Bella Coola where there is a hospital. Since then the other villages in the Agency have been asking for a similar system, and also means to furnish electric lights, where the water power allowed it.

Bella Coola.

The Indian village here is built on what was once tide flats; it is now situated about four or five feet above high tide level. The Indians have wells. Some years ago samples of water from three of these were sent to Ottawa. The analyst stated that while the water was not free from foreign matter, it was not considered dangerous to health. Fine pure water could be obtained here from a glacial stream; but the distance particularly, would make it a relatively expensive undertaking. Bella Coola has cold winters, and the pipe line must be kept from freezing.

China Hat.

This village is compactly built on sloping, wet, moss-covered ground close to salt water. The Indians get their water from surface streams; wells could not be dug. Good water from nearby streams could be obtained by a pipe line. This village, like most villages in the Agency, is practically empty during July, August, and September. The Indians are then away at the salmon canneries.

Hartley Bay.

(Skeena River Agency.)

Conditions here are similar to those at China Hat.

Kitimat.

These Indians use surface water, and have no wells. Here is a fine, glacial stream not far from the village. The pipe line would have to be dug down through land heavily wooded.

In the summer of 1915 Robt. Cucksey of Vancouver was sent by the Department to Kitimat and Hartley Bay to examine into the feasibility of establishing a water system for these villages. He sent in his reports; but the Department found the expense too great and the matter was dropped. His report for Hartley Bay is dated August 31, 1915; the estimated cost of the work is $1,755.00, the same as at Kitimat. Prices are...
higher now. I do not think that Mr. Cucksey was an engineer; but was what people generally call a "practical" man.

All the villages mentioned want water for domestic purposes, and also power to develop electric light.

I might suggest that the Department next summer send to Bella Coola a fit engineer to examine the matter of water systems. He could then be taken to the other villages in our laun the "Chas.Todd"

I believe the Indians would be willing, if able, to bear one half of the expenses in connection with the establishing of water and power systems for their villages. The sole deficiency is the matter of money. With the exception of the Bella Coola Indians none have money to their credit at Ottawa; but I understand that the Kitimats, and the China Hats have collected some money to attain the end in view.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Upon receipt of various reports from medical inspectors, etc., on the question of domestic water supplies in various Reserves in British Columbia, Indian Agent Fouger was requested to investigate this matter and report on same. The report he sent in is very brief and incomplete, and refers to the following reserves:

BELLA COOLA: The present water supply consists of wells which are exposed to contamination. A reliable water supply could be provided by building a wooden pipe line from a stream located in the vicinity of the village. The water could be conveyed to a distribution hydrant in the village where the Indians could regularly obtain their supply of water.

CHINA HAT: The Indians are now using surface water from streams on the reserve. On account of the impossibility of boring wells on this reserve, a reliable water supply could be obtained in the manner suggested for Bella Coola.

HARTLEY BAY: Conditions are similar to those at China Hat.

KITIMAT: Surface water is now being used by the Indians for domestic purposes. The question of installing an adequate water supply in this village has already been investigated in 1915, by a reliable man who reported that good water could be easily obtained from a glacial stream not far from the village. The cost of the pipe line, etc., was then estimated to cost $1,755.00.

All the above mentioned villages would also like to have electric lighting systems which would be operated by a small Hydro electric plant similar to those already in operation in other Indian villages in the agency.
These Indian bands, with the exception of Bella Coola and China Hat, have no funds to pay for an installation of this kind.

I cannot give any estimates of the cost of any of the above mentioned systems, and it is suggested by Mr. Fouger that these reserves be visited by a Civil Engineer to fully investigate the question of water supply systems, especially. There are also other villages in the agency which are in the same conditions as those above referred to which could take advantage of the engineer's presence in that district.

In view of the fact that it is impossible to perform this kind of work until next spring, I would suggest that the matter be left in abeyance, and that Indian Agent Fouger be informed that this question will be taken into consideration early next spring.

Dear Sir:

I wish to state that I visited the day school here on the 21st of March and examined the fifteen pupils present. The following day, I examined two more.

With one exception, I found that there children were in very good physical condition. This one, a little girl, had a slight temperature and a bad "cold" but I could not make out any serious lesion in her chest. I am keeping her under observation.

There were four with scabies, four had slight enlargement of some cervical glands, and nearly all had more or less hypertrophic tonsillitis. One or two should have their tonsils removed.

There is only one child in the village that I can think of who has discharging glands of neck or elsewhere and she has a discharging ear. I did not exclude her from the school when she was at home as I did not think her condition was such that she was a menace to the health of the others. Her brother also has a discharging ear. So far as I know, these are the only children of school age with these complaints. On the whole the children have had very good health this year.

Unfortunately, there is a great deal of scabies amongst the people and though some will follow directions, the majority are indifferent and will not keep up prolonged treatment. As they live in their launches, in cabins at the canneries or their camps, as well as in their homes, it is especially difficult to eradicate the pest.

Regarding tuberculosis, there are no recent cases of bone or gland infections, except the ones mentioned above and comparatively few cases of the pulmonary form. Three boys died of it in 1922. The youngest of them, a boy about 11 years old, had never attended school more than a few days. The next came home from the Boarding School in good health, the Principal thought, but his father had him examined here and definite signs were found. The father would not put him in the hospital as he was logging some eighty miles away and the boy died about six months later. The third boy, about 19, of a very tuberculous family was away at school for several years. Though not...

Sir,

I beg to report as follows, on the schools in the Bella Coola Agency:

Bella Coola Day School.

This school has good buildings with ample play-grounds, and a teacher's residence. The teacher, Mrs. Snodgrass, is an able woman, and takes interest in her work. She has a small baby to look after; but with the assistance of a grown-up sister, she ought to be able to manage. The attendance has been good; primary work only.

Bella Bella Day School.

This school has a good building; play-grounds are wild, somewhat wet land with small trees. The teacher is Miss Bertha Spencer, daughter of the missionary. She has good education, and is interested in her work. The attendance has not been what could be desired, as the Indians with their children stay away from the village a great deal of the time, at canneries, and fishing camps.

Klemtu Day School.

This school was visited by me twice during November. The building is old, and small. It has been proposed to erect a new building at this place; but the work could not be done this year, as the funds had been otherwise assigned. The teacher, Miss Blanche Randle, is young and inexperienced; but she likes her work, and the Indians spoke well of her. The attendance has been very good.

Kitimat Day School.

This school was visited by me in November. The teacher, Miss Helena J. Hare, is a woman of mature years, and has had a great deal of experience. She teaches both children from the village, and from the Residential school; the attendance of the former is not so good; of the latter it is perfect. The building is good, well lighted, and properly kept.

Kitimat Residential School.

This school was visited by me during November. The buildings are good, and well kept, situated on a hill, with a fine view of the sea. The teachers are: Principal, Miss Theo. B. Anderson; assistants, Misses; Miller, and Pasche. They are able, conscientious women.

On November 24th and 25th, I visited the Residential School at Kitimat. I am sorry not to have had the required report forms with me, and cannot give statistical information as fully, or accurately as indicated on forms. This is a school for girls; but boys are also kept till they are 12 years old. The total enrollment was 40 or 41. The pupils of this school are given class-room work in a separate building together with the village children, and taught by the day school teacher. Some time ago this caused correspondence between the Department, and United Church Authorities, apparently without results.

The school has a separate room for sick pupils; none was sick at the time of visit. The cleanliness of children, and school was very good. Playgrounds are small, but high and dry, and clean. I saw the children at meals, and they appeared well fed. Indians made no complaints relating to meals, or other matters. The children are having regular fire-drills, and fire-escapes appeared in good order. Instruction is given in cooking, household work, and sewing. There is no manual training, or farming; grounds are not suitable for gardening, being on a gravelly hill-side. Together with the Principal, I went over the building from basement to the upper story. The building is frame-work, and lighted by a delco electrical plant.

Principal, and staff are all women, and they appeared to keep the school in good order. But I understood that the staff do not think the Principal has sufficient executive ability. She is of a nervous temperament, and perhaps does not think anything is well done, unless she does it herself. I know she has had difficulty in making her reports to the Department correct, or on time. There is a likelihood of a change of Principal next year.

Kitamaat Indian Residential and Day Schools

The Kitamaat schools were last inspected on September 28th 1936.

The buildings are the property of the United Church of Canada. The day school in fact forms the classroom for the residential school pupils, almost the whole of whom in any case come from the Kitamaat Indian village.

Of the 52 children on the roll of the day school when I last visited it some 13 boys and 25 girls or 38 in all were in fact per capita drawing pupils of the residential school, while only 12 boys and 2 girls were registered as day pupils.

It has been pointed out by me on a number of occasions that at this school we pay the teacher some such salary as $90.00 or $100.00 a month to do the work for the residential school pupils which should be provided by the school from its per capita grant. If it is urged that the teacher in addition teaches the village day pupils I can only suggest that this particular activity is highly unsatisfactory for the needs of these children as has also been pointed out previously are sacrificed to those of the residential school.

Day pupils here do not always attend for the full day's session. The school is used at least partly as a step towards the residential school. Older pupils, boys for the most part and too old to continue at the residential school and for whom there may be no room at the Coqualeetza Residential School drift away from school. These older pupils boys and girls would attend a modern well organized day school of several separate Divisions, for their educational needs in the more senior Grades would then be met.

There are always a number of pupils from Kitamaat at Coqualeetza. A few may come from poor homes, but the greater number could very well be taught at an improved day school in Kitamaat. In my distribution suggestions for the pupils of Coqualeetza it was suggested that children from poor homes in Kitamaat, orphans and others, might well be sent to the Kitamaat Residential School and the pupils now at that school who come from good homes sent to either a new or enlarged day school in Kitamaat.

I am prepared to go a little further now and say that with the exception of the very few pupils who must have residential school treatment, and who could be provided for at the new Alberni Residential School the whole of the remaining Kitamaat children should be accommodated at a new Improved Indian Day School in the Kitamaat Indian village and located on Indian Reserve.

The average attendance at the present so called Kitamaat Indian Day School is quite high. This is due to the fact that the children for the greater part are those from the near by residential school.

The average quarterly attendance is given below.

| Month     | 1935-36 | 1936-37 | 1937-38 |
|-----------|---------|---------|---------|
| September | 38.7    | 39.1    | 39.7    |
| December  | 52.8    | 48.6    | 46.9    |
| March     | 46.0    | 39.9    | 45.3    |
| June      | 32.5    | 38.8    | 39.9    |

The lowest monthly average for the academic year 1937-38 was 37.3 and the highest 46.9.
The present teacher is Miss L Nelson, who would not satisfy me as to her correct age. She must be between 50 and 60 years of age. She has an Ontario Second Class Certificate. When last seen in September 1938 she appeared to have greatly aged, and it is fairly obvious that she will not be able for the active work of this large school for very much longer.

Miss Nelson lives at the Residential School and in some ways may be said to form a part of the staff. She now receives her monthly cheque direct from the Department but is called on to pay for her room and board at the Residential School.

There is a very simple solution to the present unsatisfactory conditions at Kitamaat, and I would recommend that consideration be given to the closing of the Kitamaat Indian Residential School as such.

The very few children who must have residential school treatment could be sent to either St. Michael's School Alert Bay or to the new Alberni Residential School when this is opened.

The very great majority of the Kitamaat children, including those now in the village who do not regularly attend the day school, and those who will return to Kitamaat if the Coqualestza School is closed, could well be accommodated in a new and improved day school in that village.

Such a school should have two academic class rooms for it must be able to accommodate at least 80 children. A school of somewhat the same type as St. Catherine's School, Duncan, but about half the size of that school would in my opinion be highly satisfactory.

Such a school might well be erected for less than $8,000.00. The staff would not need to include more than two classroom teachers, a janitor, a part time manual training instructor, and possibly a girls' vocational instructor. This suggestion includes what might be called a maximum staff and it would of course be under war conditions possible to operate a successful school without the girls' vocational instructor by having the classroom teachers take this subject.

An approximate saving of around $8,000.00 per year might thus be possible for as far as I can learn the total per capita allowance at the present residential school together with teacher's salary and other expenses at the day school must at present come to well over $8,000.00 per year.

You will recall that on the occasion of your recent visit to Ottawa we discussed the possibility of closing the Kitamaat Indian Residential School.

Re: Kitamaat Indian Residential and Day School

It has been pointed out on a number of occasions that at this school we pay the salary of a teacher to do the work for the residential school pupils. If it is urged that the teacher in addition teaches the village day pupils I can only suggest that this particular activity is unsatisfactory as the needs of these children, as has been pointed out previously, are sacrificed to those of the residential school.

Day pupils here do not always attend for the full day's session. The school is used at least partly as a step towards the residential school. Older pupils, boys for the most part, too old to continue at the residential school and for whom there may have been no room at the Coqualeetza Residential School, drift away from school. These older pupils, boys and girls, would attend a modern, well organized day school.

There are always a number of pupils from Kitamaat at Coqualeetza. A few may come from poor homes but the greater number could very well be taught at an improved day school at Kitamaat.

There is a very simple solution to the present unsatisfactory conditions at Kitamaat and I would recommend that consideration be given to the closing of the Kitamaat Indian Residential School as such.

The very few children who must have residential school treatment could be sent either to the Alert Bay Residential School or to the new Alberni Residential School.

The very great majority of the Kitamaat children, including those now in the village, who do not regularly attend the day school, and those who will return to Kitamaat if the Coqualeetza School is closed, could well be accommodated in a new and improved day school in that village. Such a school should have two academic class rooms for it must be able to accommodate about 80 children.

August 30th, 1909, Report re the installation of the water pipes and dam at Kitimat, B.C.

---

Rev. T. Perrier,

Upon my arrival at Kitimat in company with the Rev. C. S. Reddick I made a thorough examination of the pipe line and dam; before going up the pipe line I tested the supply in the building of the W.M.S. home, and found a very strong pressure. I then tested the fire appliances and found the whole apparatus in a good working order with a tremendous force. I had 150 feet of 1½" hose and I could throw a 1" stream from fifty to sixty feet into the air, and such a powerful force of water that I could scarcely hold the nozzle on the end of the hose. This hose with the present supply of water would throw a 1" stream around the Home, Mission House, the two school houses and Mr. Robinson's store all of which could be successfully reached in case of fire. After making this test I followed up the pipe line and found it well laid and protected from falling trees, etc., and only in three or four places did I find the pipe uncovered. I found the pipe line had been cleared from six to eight feet wide, trenches dug where possible and crib work with poles on either side filled with earth to protect the pipes. These pipes in some places are exposed or uncovered and can easily be covered but I consider they are covered as deep as I expected them to be or as deep as could be expected for the estimate I gave for the work, viz. $200.00 for digging ditch for pipes and clearing right of way, and I consider that when the pipes are covered that the work will be very satisfactory. At the dam I found that a new pipe and elbow had been put in and it was working very well, but I think when this pipe had been put into a large square box, the packing through the dam had worked loose and it leaked in two places.

I found the water in the reservoir about 4' deep with a good supply running in and a small creek running over a rocky and gravelly bottom, one coming into the reservoir out of the rock crevices— I should say it was a spring—either of these supplies or streams are sufficient to supply the Home, the larger of the two at the time of my visit was sufficient to supply a village of from 100 to 200 people. The dam has been well built and has stood the spring frosts. The Rev. Mr. Reddick assured me that until recently the dam had held the reservoir full of water, so that it ran over at the outlet or overflow provided. This being the case it can be repaired and the pipes covered then I think they will have a water supply well worth the money invested.

I shall make arrangements to have the pipes covered and the leaks stopped in the dam, either sending up the contractor, or as suggested by Miss Jackson and Rev. Mr. Reddick, get it done by Mr. Moore who resides at Kitimat, a thoroughly practical man as I can see by some odd jobs he has done at the Home for the W.M.S. Mr. Moore was not at home when I was there but he is expected back by the 10th. or 12th. of September, and I am in hopes of getting him to do this work at once, but there is no immediate necessity as the supply is ample, but I propose to have it put in good condition as soon as possible, and before I make final payment to the contractor.

Re the water supply for the Indians of the village, there is a three inch pipe brought from the Home down to the sidewalk line, just in front of the picket fence at the north west corner of the Mission house property, at this point we have put a stand pipe with tap for the use of the Indians but they take no care whatever of it, they have destroyed one or two. I had a new one put in before I left.

I understand the Indians want the pipes carried down the main street and stand pipes put to each house, if you did that for the Indians they would want their homes piped. Personally, I think they have been treated very generously, particularly as they refuse to render any assistance to help clear the right of way or pack any of the materials up onto the premises when the work was being done.

Re the supply giving out last winter from what I gathered from Rev. Mr. C. S. Reddick and other I should say it was not that the supply gave out but that it froze up in the pipes. I am sure had the main line pipe been left open at the lower end they would hav...
had water all winter, for with the amount of snow they have up there there is little or no frost in the ground in the winter time and the small streams as a general thing do not freeze up dry and one of the streams I think is large enough to run all winter. Our main line of pipe are of wood and therefore not so liable to freeze as iron pipes and the pipes being covered with at least four to six inches of dirt and generally about five feet of snow should not freeze up if left open at the lower end. If a little careful attention were given at the fall of the year at the dam end to watch the intake and see that it is properly covered and protected and that the overflow of the reservoir has not uncovered or washed away the covering of the main supply pipe during the summer season. By following these instructions the pipes would not get full of ice as they did last winter and stay full until late in the month of June. There was abundance of water and the reservoir was overflowing long before the pipes were thawed out. The streams run under the snow all winter in this Province (that is along the coast) and although last winter was the most severe in 20 years I am of the opinion that had the outlet at the lower end of our main line of pipe been left open we should have had water all through the winter. It might have stopped running during the few days of the most severe weather, but it would have been a very short time, if at all.

In addition to leaving the lower end open and protecting the intake and the dam, all the valves or iron connections should be well protected by being covered securely against frost.

Respectfully submitted,

(Sgd) Thomas Hopper.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your favor of the 9th re the water supply for Kitimat, the church spent $1500 putting in this water system, and at the time it was fully expected that this would give us an abundance of water in a workable system the year round. I enclose you a copy of the report made by Mr. Thomas Hooper, the architect. You will see from this that we had every reason to believe that the question of a suitable water supply was settled. What Mr. Green means by placing the pipe under ground, I presume is that the pipe has got uncovered in certain places. My own judgment, at the time the system was installed, was that the pipe should have been laid at least two feet under ground, but the architect claimed that there was no danger of frost in the B.C. climate if it had any kind of protection as the frost never went into the ground. While I have never been at Kitimat since the school was built and the water system installed, I am well aware that the water system has not been satisfactory. At the time it was installed there was considerable correspondence between myself and the Department re the necessary expenditure. My contention at the time was that, in-as-much as the overflow of water was to be for use by the people of the village, the Department should pay some portion of the outlay. It is just possible that if the Department were to make a grant of a thousand or fifteen hundred dollars for this purpose the system could be made satisfactory for both the school and the village. It is very
evident that something ought to be done. Personally, I would not make any recommendations without being on the ground and making an inspection of the whole situation.

Sirs:

I beg to submit the following report of my visit to China Hat, Hartley Bay and Kitamaat in September.

In order to leave an assistant in charge while I was away it was necessary for me to make this trip early in September. Unfortunately, as this was a time when a great many of the Indians were away at their salmon smoking camps, I only saw a few of them. In fact, at Hartley Bay there were only three at home - an old couple and a boy who was helping them. I extracted a tooth for the old man and prescribed for the old blind lady who had hurt her back. Mr. Matthews, the teacher missionary, was glad to see me, as he had been sick for several weeks.

At China Hat, I saw a number of people, prescribing for some and extracting teeth for others.

I left Bella Bella on September 11th, in the hospital launch "Kia-quack", reaching China Hat the same night. I made what calls were necessary the next morning and then proceeded, anchoring for the night in Ursula channel. I arrived at Kitamaat the afternoon of the 13th and remained there until the morning of the 16th.

Many of the Kitamaat people were at the Prince Rupert fair in which their football team takes a prominent part, and some were up river smoking salmon. When word got up that I was there, a number came down for consultations and I was able to examine one or two of the children for admission to the "Home".

I found the staff and pupils at the "Home" quite well, having had no serious cases of illness recently. As a number had had trouble with their throats, I examined them at once and prepared to operate on four the following morning.

With Nurse Alton's help and that of the nurse whom I had taken with me, I removed the tonsils and adenoids of these four girls Thursday morning and spent the rest of the day examining...
her pupils. On Friday, I inspected the "Home", finished my examinations there, and made several calls in the village. I found one child dying with pulmonary tuberculosis and gave the Mother necessary directions for helping the child and at the same time safeguarding the rest of the family.

On the whole, I found conditions fairly satisfactory, though, of course, with so many people away from home, my observations were necessarily limited.

It is fortunate that these villages are unoccupied to such a large extent during the summer months, as none of them have an adequate water supply. At Kitamaat, they depend upon shallow wells dug near their houses, while at China Hat and Hartley Bay, they use rain water from their roofs or carry from the nearby creeks. In a dry season, such as this has been, what little water was available was hardly safe to use. The people should be encouraged to install running water systems, as soon as they can manage it.

Chiefly for its educational value, I made a nominal charge of $2.00 an examination outside of the "Home" and collected $15.50.

With special reference to the Boarding School, I think that the children were in very good condition. However, I made some suggestions to Miss Clarke in regard to giving the children raw fruit, raisins or something of that sort, etc., regularly during the winter, as well as a little more butter. Several of the pupils have pyorrhea in spite of regular teeth brushing with Colgate's paste. I would suggest that the Department consult a dentist and if possible use something more preventative than this, and also give Miss Alton instructions for treating the present cases.

I think a lung meter, such as is used in some gymnasiums, would be a good investment. Routine exercises become a bore, unless the children can see that they are accomplishing something. By blowing in this instrument, the lung capacity can be measured and in trying to excel one another, each child will be benefitted.

Another thing which would be of assistance in keeping track of the welfare of the pupils would be a regular printed chart for recording the weekly temperatures and weights. By having these
recorded graphically, any tendency to decline would be noticed much more readily than if they were merely written down and perhaps before anything would be observed in the child herself. I attach herewith a specimen for illustration.

In conclusion, I would recommend that the men of the village be asked to cut down all the trees on the knoll behind the "Home". It would not take them more than a few hours and the children would have at least an extra hour of sunlight in their dormitories. That may not sound a great deal, but in this climate where the sun may not be seen for days and even weeks at a time, every hour is very very important.

Yours faithfully,

George E. Darby
Medical Superintendent, The R.W. Large Memorial Hospital, Bella Bella, B.C.

Inspector's Report on Bella Coola Agency No. 1.

Sir,

I met the principal, Mrs. Rinacre, of the Residential school on Kitimat Reserve No. 2. She complained of the difficulty of collecting the children from the various canneries at the end of the holidays. The building was well kept and in good order. I found, however, that they were still using oil lamps, a dangerous thing in a school so out of the way, and where the water supply for fire purposes is low at certain times of the year. This building should have a delco installed. Having in view the danger from fire I thoroughly inspected the building from that point of view. I found that the fire extinguishers ought to be refilled. There is no system of fire alarm bells. The fire escape for the girls is well situated. For the boys, who are all quite young, the fire escape from the small dormitory is very difficult to get at and hard for small children to use, being only an iron ladder set to one side of the window. The third story where other small boys are, has no fire escape. The furnace, a good one, was situated in the basement; concrete sides and part of the floor. This basement was kept tidy. I instructed the principal to keep the ends of the fire hose screwed to the stand pipes knowing the difficulty of adjusting them in the dark. However as I said before the supply of water is very doubtful and they would probably have to depend upon extinguishers. I found, like so many schools, that no fire drill had been organized, and I commented to the principal upon this.

G.S. Pragnell,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Replying to yours of Aug. 14th. regarding an electric lighting plant for the Kitimat Indian School I would recommend a full automatic, 750 watt, 32 volt, Delco Light system, Model 750.

Fire Protection:

There are 4 inside stand pipes, with a length of 1½ inch hose attached to each. There are 12 Diamond dry extinguishers and 4 soda type extinguishers. There is a reel of hose on a portable stand. As I considered the pressure in the ordinary water pipes to be very small, less than five pounds, I had the hose in the basement of the school taken down, and the water turned on. The basement hose was chosen as the pressure in it would be greater than in those on the floors above. Mr. Indian Agent Founger was present at this test.

The result was just as I had expected. The water just managed to get through the hose and to rise to a height of about a foot above the nozzle. It may be taken as a fact that the standpipes and hose are quite useless in the case of a fire.

In two cases stove pipes pass through the interior walls of the building. This of course tends to increase the fire risk.

About two years ago a very fine fire escape was provided. It serves the boys' dormitory and the senior girls' dormitory. The junior girls are expected to cross a corridor, go into the Principal's room and then down a very dangerous escape which ends for no sensible reason 8 feet above the ground. The iron platform at the top of this escape should be extended to pass under the window of the Junior Girls' Dormitory. Another iron strap rail should be added to this escape to prevent small children falling through, and the escape should be continued to the ground. There is, however, another solution of the problem of escape from the Junior Girls' Dormitory which would not cost more than a few dollars.

At present there is an old iron fire ladder on the ground beside the school. I have measured the ladder and the height of the windows in this junior dormitory. The iron fire ladder could be bolted to the wall of the school with six large bolts. The ladder would reach from about two feet above the bottom of the window to within three feet of the ground. It should be placed so that the ladder
ladder was at the side of the window. I think that even small children would be able to climb down by this ladder if absolutely necessary. This latter solution though in some ways not quite as good as the more expensive one of an addition to the present escape is the one that I wish to recommend to the Department.

The window leading from the Senior Girls' room to the fire escape has a small nail in it to prevent boys opening the window from outside. As there is an axe hung in clips beside the window, I do not think there is any danger.

Water Supply:

The source of the water supply is in a small stream through the woods on the hill at the back of the school. This stream, which is dry in the summer, is led through a wooden pipe into a small shallow pool. The pool is about 50 yards in circumference and perhaps 6 feet deep in the centre. The nature of the soil is heavy clay, and the pool rapidly shelves to the banks. The pipe that conveys the water to the school is now about three feet below the normal level of the surface.

Last year the school was without water for some time during the summer, as the pool had dried up.

To give a proper supply of water to the school, a cement dam and a fairly large tank should be constructed. To save money and still increase the amount of water available during the summer months, I would suggest that a day's work be done on the present spillway. The spillway is about two feet below the top of the retaining bank or dam. This spillway could very easily be raised another foot, by filling in with earth and boards. This would increase the amount of water retained in the pool and would not cost much.
Ottawa, May 26th, 1931.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. G. H. BARRY, INSPECTOR OF SCHOOLS, ON HIS VISIT TO THE KITAMAAT RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL ON MAY 16TH, LAST.

GENERAL RECOMMENDATION:

I do not consider that the children from this residential school should be permitted to crowd the village children out of the day school. At present the only way to keep the number of children attending the Indian day school within bounds is to send a number of the boys to Coqualeetza Indian Residential School. Even then the day school is overcrowded and I am not convinced that all the boys from the village are attending this day school when still of school age.

As has been reported previously, please see the report on Kitamaat Indian Day School dated May 17, 1932, there is a definite need for a second classroom at Kitamaat. To save the Department the expense of erecting such a room and providing a teacher for the Second Division thus formed, I would ask that consideration be given to the following recommendation:

I would recommend that the United Church of Canada be asked to consider building an addition to the Elizabeth Long Memorial Home. This addition should be large enough to give a good sized schoolroom on the ground floor, and a fair sized dormitory with an additional teacher's room above it. The addition suggested is much the same as that lately added to the Port Simpson Indian Residential School.

I would ask that consideration be given to increasing the number of children authorized to draw Per Capita Grants from 42 to 50 on the understanding that the Church Authorities provided the salary for the teacher for the proposed schoolroom. This would free the Indian Day School for its rightful purpose of accommodating the village children, who should not be sent to Coqualeetza except in exceptional circumstances. The above is submitted for the information of the Department, as it is believed that economy might thereby be effected.
Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Superintendent of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

In his report of September 28th on the Kitimat Indian Residential School, Inspector Barry referred to the retaining wall of the playground as giving way. Mr. Indian Agent Gillett was asked to investigate the matter on his first trip to the school, which he did and reported as follows:

"I have made a thorough investigation concerning the above, and deem repairs are necessary. The playground is made on a hillside, and is 60 by 50 feet, with a cement wall on two sides. The wall is 106 feet long, the highest part of the wall being 11 feet and the lowest 4 feet. Both walls have cracked, and are leaning over the sidewalk, and may be dangerous to the children who use the walk continually. The cost of a new cement wall would be at least $500.

Instead of erecting a new wall, I would recommend the wall and playground to be lowered two feet. The sand and gravel from the playground could be dumped along the outside of the cement wall, thus preventing the wall from tumbling over. This would cost approximately $250.

Moving 180 yards of sand and gravel and placing broken cement at base of wall $200.00
5 sacks of cement 5.50
Breaking off cement from wall 10.00
Lumber for extra sidewalk 10.00
Labor moving and rebuilding part of sidewalk 5.00
Cartage on cement and lumber and unforeseen expenses. 10.00

$250.00"

The Secretary,

Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant with reference to the disposal of a 750 watt, 32 volt, Type A Canadian Fairbanks Morse Company lighting plant at the Kitimat Indian Residential School.

While it is noted that you do not favor installing it in any Indian Day School, I would advise that the new two-room school and residence at Kitimat is fully wired for electric light, other than drop cords, sockets and globes. During the winter months this school is sufficiently far north and subject to almost continually overcast sky to make work in the class rooms most difficult without some form of lighting, particularly in the two basement rooms set aside for manual training and domestic science. As the old residential school is not more than about one hundred yards distant from the new school and the Agent and his engineer are familiar with these plants, one having been in operation for some years in the Agency office, the plant could no doubt be moved over to the school for a small amount for labor. In addition, drop cords, globes, etc. would be required.

Under the circumstances, it would appear that an exception might be made in this case, provided the change over could be carried out without much cost and the Agent, or the engineer, agreed to make a regular check on the plant and batteries in order to avoid unnecessary cost of replacements and repairs.
